Description: THE PALA WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT PLAN (PWMP) INTENDS TO ASSESS CURRENT HABITATS AND VEGETATION HEALTH THROUGHOUT THE PALA RESERVATION AND PROVIDE SPECIFIC RECOMMENDATIONS FOR RESTORING AND MAINTAINING THE HEALTH OF THE MANY ECOSYSTEMS ON TRIBAL LANDS. THIS PROJECT WILL ALSO ESTABLISH A PALA TRIBAL NURSERY, WHICH WILL CULTIVATE NATIVE AND CULTURALLY IMPORTANT PLANT SPECIES FOR FUTURE RESTORATION NEEDS FOUND BY THE PWMP. THE PROJECT DURATION IS ANTICIPATED TO BE 18 MONTHS AND INVOLVE PERFORMING NEW RIPARIAN HABITAT AND OAK HEALTH SURVEYS. INVENTORIES OF NATIVE AND INVASIVE SPECIES WILL BE COMPILED INTO A DATABASE AND MAPPED. INFORMATION FROM THESE ACTIVITIES WILL BE USED TO INFORM THE WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT PLAN AND THE SEEDS AND PLANT CUTTINGS THAT WILL BE COLLECTED FOR THE TRIBAL NURSERY. INFORMATION FROM THESE ACTIVITIES WILL INFORM WORKSHOPS BETWEEN THE PALA ENVIRONMENTAL DEPARTMENT (PED) AND OTHER TRIBES IN THE SAN LUIS REY RIVER VALLEY.

INDIGENOUS PEOPLES OF THE ROUND VALLEY INDIAN TRIBES (RVIT) HAVE RESIDED IN THE EEL RIVER WATERSHED LONG BEFORE THE RESERVATION WAS ESTABLISHED. ITS WATER RESOURCES AND FISHERIES HOLD STRONG SPIRITUAL, CULTURAL, AND UTILITARIAN IMPORTANCE TO ITS PEOPLE, AND TRADITIONAL RVIT LAND MANAGEMENT PRACTICES PROMOTED THESE RESOURCES. RESTORING THE WATERSHED TO SUPPORT HEALTHY RUNS OF SALMON AND STEELHEAD IS CRITICAL FOR THE RVIT TO INTERACT WITH THEIR HISTORICAL AND CULTURAL ROOTS AND MAINTAIN THEIR CULTURAL LIFEWAYS IN WHICH FISH ARE A CULTURAL, SPIRITUAL, AND SUBSISTENCE RESOURCE.   THIS PROJECT WOULD SUPPORT THE DEVELOPMENT OF A TIME AND COST-EFFICIENT SONAR FISHERIES MONITORING PROGRAM IN THE MIDDLE FORK EEL RIVER AND ALLOW THE ROUND VALLEY INDIAN TRIBES TO ESTABLISH POPULATION ESTIMATES OF CHINOOK SALMON AND STEELHEAD TROUT NEEDED TO INFORM FUTURE RESTORATION, MANAGEMENT AND REGULATORY PRIORITIES WHILE ALSO BUILDING CAPACITY WITHIN A DEVELOPING TRIBAL FISHERIES PROGRAM. THE PROPOSED PROJECT WILL ACHIEVE THREE KEY OBJECTIVES FOR THE RVIT AND FOR STAKEHOLDERS IN THE WATERSHED: CONTINUING INTERNAL CAPACITY BUILDING OF THE RVIT FISHERIES PROGRAM, MONITORING ADULT ANADROMOUS SALMONIDS ESCAPEMENT ON THE MIDDLE FORK OF THE EEL RIVER, AND INFORMING RESTORATION AND CONSERVATION ACTIONS THROUGH THE EEL RIVER, INCLUDING THE MIDDLE FORK, POTTER VALLEY PROJECT, AND ELSEWHERE.

THE SEMINOLE TRIBE OF FLORIDA (TRIBE) LANDS SPAN ACROSS 88,143 ACRES OF WHAT IS CONSIDERED TO BE ONE OF THE MOST UNIQUE HABITATS IN THE WORLD, THE FLORIDA EVERGLADES. THE DIVERSE HABITATS FOUND IN THE EVERGLADES HOME DOZENS OF FEDERALLY LISTED THREATENED, ENDANGERED, AND PROTECTED SPECIES INCLUDING: THE FLORIDA PANTHER, NORTHERN CRESTED CARACARA, EASTERN INDIGO SNAKE, BALD EAGLE, EVERGLADES SNAIL KITE, RED-COCKADED WOODPECKER, FLORIDA BONNETED BAT, AND WORD STORK. TRIBAL LANDS PROVIDE THESE SPECIES WITH A VARIETY OF SENSITIVE HABITATS SUCH AS FRESHWATER PONDS, PRAIRIES, SAWGRASS MARSHES, AND FORESTED UPLANDS. THE SEMINOLE TRIBE SHARES A CONNECTION TO THE RESOURCES PROVIDED THROUGHOUT THE EVERGLADES THAT HAVE HISTORICALLY PROVIDED THE COMMUNITY WITH FOOD, SHELTER AND MEDICINAL RESOURCES. THESE LANDSCAPES CONTINUE TO PROVIDE NATURAL AND CULTURAL RESOURCES TO THE TRIBE TODAY WHICH HAS RESULTED IN THE TRIBE PLACING GREAT EMPHASIS AND PRIDE IN MANAGING THESE NATURAL RESOURCES. THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE 2012 TRIBAL COUNCIL APPROVED SEMINOLE TRIBE OF FLORIDA WILDLIFE CONSERVATION PLAN (WCP) ALLOWS THE TRIBE TO PRACTICE SUSTAINABLE NATURAL AND CULTURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT. THE WCP RESULTED FROM SEVERAL YEARS OF COORDINATION WITH THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (SERVICE) AND WAS PRESENTED BY THE BUREAU OF INDIAN AFFAIRS (BIA) ON THE TRIBES BEHALF WHERE A BIOLOGICAL OPINION (CONSULTATION CODE: 2013-CPA-0222) WAS RECEIVED ON DECEMBER 19TH, 2014. THE MULTI-AGENCY DEVELOPMENT OF THE WCP HAS PROVIDED THE TRIBE WITH THE ABILITY TO CONTINUE SUSTAINABLE USE PRACTICES AND PROTECTION OF WILDLIFE  WHILE BALANCING MANAGEMENT OBJECTIVES TO ENSURE THAT A DISPROPORTIONATE BURDEN IS NOT PLACED ON THE TRIBE THROUGH CONFORMITY WITH THE POLICY OF THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT. THROUGH THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THIS TOOL THE TRIBE HAS BEEN PROVIDED WITH THE ABILITY TO PRACTICE SELF-SUFFICIENCY AND MAINTAIN TRIBAL SOVEREIGNTY THROUGH CAPACITY BUILDING WHILE CARRYING OUT THE TRIBAL COUNCILS DIRECTIVE. THE FUNDING REQUESTED WITHIN THIS PROPOSAL WILL PROVIDE THE TRIBE WITH THE ABILITY TO ACHIEVE NATURAL AND CULTURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT OBJECTIVES BY COLLECTING DATA ON THREATENED AND ENDANGERED SPECIES, MONITORING AND ENHANCING HABITAT, PROTECTING NATURAL RESOURCES, AND FOSTERING A SENSE OF COMMUNITY INVOLVEMENT AND AWARENESS THROUGH EDUCATION AND OUTREACH PROGRAMS. THE TRIBE RESPECTFULLY REQUESTS  200,000.00 (67.52  OF PROJECT COSTS) FOR THE PERIOD OF OCTOBER 1, 2022 TO SEPTEMBER 30, 2023. THESE FUNDS WILL BE COST-SHARED WITH  75,100.00 (37.55 ) OF PROJECT COSTS IN THE FORM OF TRIBAL IN-KIND CONTRIBUTIONS.

THE PYRAMID LAKE FISHERIES (PLF) IS DELEGATED AUTHORITY TO OPERATE, SERVICE, AND MAINTAIN THE PYRAMID LAKE FISHERY PRODUCTION AND ALL OF THE NATURAL ATTRIBUTES ASSOCIATED WITH THE BIOLOGICAL ECOSYSTEM IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE PYRAMID LAKE FISHERY CONSERVATION PLAN OF 1992. THE PRODUCTION LEVELS FOR THE ENDEMIC CUI UI FISH AND THE LAHONTAN CUTTHROAT TROUT (LCT) ARE LIMITED BY A NUMBER OF HISTORICAL ACTIONS THAT HAVE ALTERED THE NATURAL LIFE CYCLES OF THE CUI UI AND LCT, AND THROUGH TO TODAY HUMAN ACTIONS CONTINUE TO ALTER THE NATURAL LIFE CYCLES OF THE PYRAMID LAKE FISHERY. THE CUI UI AND LCT BOTH HAVE RECOVERY PLANS THAT CONTAIN CRITERIA AND OBJECTIVES THAT ARE AIMED AT RESTORATION AND RECOVERY EFFORT FOR THE LOWER TRUCKEE RIVER AND PYRAMID LAKE. EACH RECOVERY PLAN CONTAINS MERIT CRITERIA FOR BROOD STOCK OPERATIONS AS AN IMPORTANT COMPONENT TO THE RECOVERY AND RESTORATION OF THE CUI UI AND LCT. THE PLF IS RESPONSIBLE FOR THE SUCCESSFUL PROPAGATION OF THE ENDANGERED CUI UI AND THREATENED LAHONTAN CUTTHROAT TROUT (LCT) FISH OF PYRAMID LAKE. TO MAINTAIN AND ACHIEVE LCT SPAWNING SUCCESS, PROPER FACILITIES ARE REQUIRED TO SERVE EACH PHASE OF REARING LCT FROM SPAWNING TO RELEASE. CERTAIN REARING POOLS ARE UTILIZED FOR NECESSARY PYRAMID LAKE ACCLAMATION AND THE POOLS UTILIZED FOR THIS PURPOSE ARE AGED AND WORN FROM WHICH REPLACEMENT IS THE VIABLE AND FEASIBLE OPTION FOR CONTINUED USE FOR THIS STAGE OF REARING. THE POOLS ARE USED DURING THE FINAL STAGE OF REARING LCT TO ACCLIMATE THE FISH TO PYRAMID LAKE WATER PRIOR TO BEING RELEASED OR STOCKED IN PYRAMID LAKE. THIS STEP IS IMPORTANT TO EXPERIENCE INCREASED VIABILITY FOR LCT SURVIVAL. THIS PROPOSED OBJECTIVE WILL REPLACE SIX AGED AND WORN POOLS THAT WILL PROVIDE EFFICIENT FUNCTION TO THE REARING PROCESS.THE PROPAGATION AND REARING OF CUI UI (PRONOUNCED KOOYOO EE) HAS EXPERIENCED CHALLENGES OVER TIME WITH THE PLF EFFORT TO MAINTAIN SUCCESS WITH CUI UI SPAWNING PRODUCTION. THE BIG BEND CUI UI REARING FACILITY IS AN OPERATION THAT HAS BECOME LIMITED DUE TO THE SIZE OF THE WELL AND PUMP AT THE FACILITY. THE WELL AND PUMP CAN PRODUCE APPROXIMATELY 30 GALLONS PER MINUTE. THE OPERATION IS ADJUSTED AND ALTERED BECAUSE OF THE LIMITED WATER FLOW AND INCREASE IN PRODUCTION REQUIRES THE WELL OUTPUT TO 60 GALLONS PER MINUTE. AS AN ENDANGERED SPECIES, THE PROPAGATION IS PERFORMED AT THE TRUCKEE RIVER THAT PROVIDES THE NATURAL RELEASE OF HATCHED LARVAE DIRECTLY TO THE RIVER. THIS PROPOSED OBJECTIVE WILL INCREASE THE WELL OUTPUT TO 60 GALLONS PER MINUTE INTENDED TO BRINGING THE FACILITY TO FULL OPERATION.

THE NEED FOR THE SSBMI TWG PROJECT IS TO IDENTIFY TARGET SPECIES AND HABITATS OF ENDANGERED AND CULTURAL FAUNA AND ANIMALS ON THE SHINGLE SPRINGS BAND OF MIWOK INDIANS NEWLY ACQUIRED PROPERTY.  THE NEWLY ACQUIRED INDIAN CREEK RANCH (PROPERTY) CONTAINS 180 ACRES OF UNDEVELOPED LAND, ZONED FOR HOUSING DEVELOPMENT.  THE PROPERTY CONTAINS A LARGE POND (INCLUDED PROPERTY MAPS IN H. PROJECT LOCATION) APPROXIMATELY 600 YARDS IN LENGTH AND 82 YARDS IN WIDTH.  THIS POND AND SURROUNDING 180 ACRES HABITATS MAY CONTAIN CALIFORNIA RED LEGGED FROG (CRLF), VALLEY ELDERBERRY LONGHORN BEETLE (VELB), OTHER TARGET AQUATIC, RIPARIAN, FAUNA, AND ANIMAL SPECIES.  THE TRIBE PURCHASED THE PROPERTY FOR HOUSING DEVELOPMENT, HOWEVER BEING STEWARDS OF THE LAND, THE TRIBE WILL CONSERVE AS MUCH OF THE 180 ACRE PROPERTY AS POSSIBLE FOR CONSERVATION OF CRLF, VELB, RIPARIAN, AQUATIC, TRADITIONAL FAUNA, AND ANIMAL SPECIES.  THE NEED FOR THE TRIBE TO CONDUCT TARGETED SPECIES AND HABITAT STUDIES ON THE PROPERTY IS CRITICAL TO THE TRIBES CONSERVATION EFFORTS AND PROMISES TO THEIR TRIBAL MEMBERS.  THE SSBMI TWG PROJECT SHALL INCLUDE HIRING A PROFESSIONAL CONSULTANT TO CONDUCT CRLF, VELB, RIPARIAN, AQUATIC, FAUNA AND ANIMAL SPECIES ASSESSMENTS STUDIES OF THE PROPERTY AND MAP OUT KEY HABITAT AREAS FOR CONSERVATION EFFORTS.  THE CONSULTANT SHALL PROVIDE TRAINING AND MENTORING TO A TRIBAL ENVIRONMENTAL INTERN DURING ASSESSMENT AND MAPPING OF THE PROJECT.  THE PROJECT IS ESTIMATED TO BE COMPLETELY FINALIZED WITHIN 12 MONTHS OF THE PROJECT START DATE.

WE PROPOSE TO INSTALL LOG JAM AND BOULDER STRUCTURES REQUIRING 100 TREES AND 150 BOULDERS TO RESTORE IN STREAM HABITAT COMPLEXITY, LONG TERM STABILITY, AND ENHANCE FISH HABITAT QUALITY IN A  MILE STRETCH OF THE MAIN STEM OF THE MEDUXNEKEAG RIVER BELOW WHERE I 95 CROSSES THE RIVER AND SOUTH AND UPSTREAM OF MALISEET RIVERSIDE VILLAGE. THIS STRETCH IS JUST UPSTREAM OF ANOTHER 3 4 MILE STRETCH WE EXPECT TO COMPLETE IN 2022 AND 3.8 MILES OF RESTORATION COMPLETED ON THE MAIN STEM AS OF 2020. THIS PROJECT CONTINUES AN ESTABLISHED AND LONG TERM EFFORT BY HBMI TO RESTORE AQUATIC HABITAT AND IMPROVE WATER QUALITY IN THE MEDUXNEKEAG WATERSHED BY MITIGATING LEGACY IMPACTS OF LOGGING AND DAMS IN THIS HISTORICAL SALMON STREAM. HBMI WILL CONTINUE CONTRACTING WITH JOHN FIELD, FLUVIAL GEOMORPHOLOGIST AND CERTIFIED USDA, NRCS TECHNICAL SERVICE PROVIDER FOR PROJECT DESIGN AND IMPLEMENTATION. FIELD IS THE AUTHOR OF OUR AQUATIC HABITAT STUDY FOR THE MEDUXNEKEAG WATERSHED. NATURAL   EXISTING LOG JAM AND BOULDER STRUCTURES FIELD OBSERVED IN THE WATERSHED WILL BE REPLICATED TO IMPROVE HABITAT CONDITIONS FOR WILD BROOK TROUT AT THE RESTORATION SITE. MAIN PROJECT TASKS INCLUDE (1) GATHERING  ACQUIRING PROJECT MATERIALS (BOULDERS AND TREES WITH ROOT WADS), (2) OBTAINING STATE FEDERAL PERMITS, (3) INSTALLING HYDRO MODIFICATION BMPS (BOULDER AND LOG STRUCTURES THAT CREATE SHADE, RIFFLES AND POOLS),(4) PHOTOGRAPHING AND RESURVEYING THE CHANNEL AND CHANNEL FEATURES TO DOCUMENT RESULTING CHANGES (5) CONDUCTING LONG TERM MONITORING FIELD TRIAL, AND (6) PROVIDING EDUCATION AND OUTREACH TO OUR TRIBAL AND WATERSHED COMMUNITIES. A CONSIDERABLE AMOUNT OF BOULDERS AND WOODY DEBRIS WERE LOST FROM THE MEDUXNEKEAG IN THE 1800S. THIS LACK OF POOL AND RIFFLE FORMING FEATURES CREATED WIDE, SHALLOW STREAM CHANNELS WITH LITTLE STRUCTURAL COMPLEXITY AND IMPAIRED AQUATIC HABITAT. THE SHALLOW, SLOW MOVING WATER WARMS MORE QUICKLY CONTRIBUTING TO TEMPERATURES ALSO UNSUITABLE FOR THE RIVERS COLD WATER FISH AND OTHER AQUATIC ORGANISMS. ANTICIPATED ENVIRONMENTAL OUTCOMES INCLUDE  (1) IMPROVED AQUATIC HABITAT (POOLS, RIFFLES, SHADE) AND (2) INCREASED OPPORTUNITY FOR COLD WATER FISH SUCH AS SALMON TO MIGRATE UPSTREAM INTO TRIBAL WATERS AND TO REACH COLD WATER REFUGIA IN ADJACENT TRIBUTARIES. ONE OF HBMIS OVERARCHING NATURAL RESOURCE GOALS IS SALMON IN OUR WATERS.

THE POKAGON BAND OF POTAWATOMI INDIANS (POKAGON BAND) PROPOSES TO PERFORM SURVEYS TO DETERMINE THE PRESENCE AND SPECIES COMPOSITION OF LEPIDOPTERANS ON TRIBAL PROPERTIES, WITH A FOCUS ON SEARCHING FOR MONARCH (DANAUS PLEXIPPUS) AND REGAL FRITILLARY (ARGYNNIS IDALIA).  BUTTERFLIES ARE OF CULTURAL SIGNIFICANCE TO THE POKAGON BAND, AND STORIES IN THE POTAWATOMI ORAL TRADITION HIGHLIGHT BUTTERFLIES AND THEIR ROLE IN THE BALANCE OF CREATION. THE PROJECT SEEKS TO ACHIEVE THE FOLLOWING OBJECTIVES OBJECTIVE 1  SURVEY FOR LEPIDOPTERAN BUTTERFLIES ON TRIBAL PROPERTIES ANNUALLY FOR THREE YEARS TO DETERMINE PRESENCE OR ABSENCE.OBJECTIVE 2  COMPLETE FLOWERING PLANT SURVEYS ON TRIBAL PROPERTIES TO DETERMINE BLOOMING FLORAL DIVERSITY COMPOSITION ALONG SURVEY TRANSECTS.OBJECTIVE 3  RAISE AWARENESS OF ENDANGERED AND THREATENED SPECIES THAT MAY BE FOUND ON TRIBAL PROPERTIES.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES  THE POKAGON BAND EXPECTS TO IDENTIFY MULTIPLE GENERALIST AND SPECIALIST LEPIDOPTERAN SPECIES DURING POLLARD WALK AND CHECKLIST SURVEYS. THE POKAGON BAND ALSO EXPECTS TO BETTER UNDERSTAND THE COMPOSITION OF PRODUCTIVE FLORAL DIVERSITY ALONG SURVEY TRANSECTS, WHICH MAY ASSIST IN DEVELOPING FUTURE SEED MIXTURES TO BE PLANTED ON TRIBAL PROPERTIES. IF REGALS ARE DISCOVERED, TRIBAL PROPERTIES WILL BE MANAGED TO HELP PROTECT THIS SPECIES. WOODY STEM DENSITY IS EXPECTED TO BE REDUCED BY AT LEAST 50  DURING INITIAL TREATMENTS AND MAINTAINED AT OR BELOW THIS DENSITY FOR THE DURATION OF THE PROJECT. THE POKAGON BAND ANTICIPATES THAT LEPIDOPTERAN DIVERSITY AND POPULATION SIZE WILL BE HIGHER IN AREAS WITH LESS WOODY ENCROACHMENT, AND THAT FLORAL DIVERSITY WILL BE HIGHER IN AREAS FOLLOWING PRESCRIBED FIRE. FINALLY, AT LEAST 250 SHIRTS AND BROCHURES WILL BE DISTRIBUTED AT EDUCATIONAL EVENTS, AND MONARCH CATERPILLARS WILL BE RAISED EACH YEAR FOR RELEASE.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES  THE POKAGON BAND TRIBAL COMMUNITY. DATA AND RESULTS WILL ALSO BE SHARED WITH THE FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE AND THE UDSA NATURAL RESOURCES CONSERVATION SERVICE.

THE WIYOT TRIBE SHARES ITS NAME WITH ITS ANCESTRAL RIVER, WIYOT, WHICH TRANSLATES AS ABUNDANCE. A SIGNIFICANT ASPECT OF THAT ABUNDANCE WAS THE GOU DAW, PACIFIC LAMPREY (ENTOSPHENUS TRIDENTATUS)  COMMONLY CALLED EELS, WHICH INSPIRED THE RIVERS ENGLISH NAME, EEL RIVER. THE EEL RIVER WATERSHED IS THE THIRD LARGEST IN CALIFORNIA AND WAS ONCE HOME TO ABUNDANT RUNS OF SALMON, STEELHEAD, STURGEON, AND PACIFIC LAMPREY. NUMEROUS IMPACTS, INCLUDING WATER DIVERSIONS, INVASIVE PREDATORS, LOGGING, AND SEDIMENTATION, HAVE LED TO SIGNIFICANT ECOLOGICAL AND HABITAT DEGRADATION AND DIMINISHED NATIVE FISH POPULATIONS THAT ARE IMPORTANT TO THE WIYOT TRIBE. THE TRIBE IS RENEWING ITS TRADITIONAL ROLE AS ACTIVE STEWARDS OF THE NATURAL RESOURCES IN ITS ANCESTRAL TERRITORY, AND IN RECENT YEARS HAS BEEN A DRIVING FORCE FOR ACTIVITIES AIMED AT RESTORING POPULATIONS OF PACIFIC LAMPREY AND OTHER NATIVE FISHES. HEREIN, THE TRIBE PROPOSES TO BUILD ON ITS WORK AND THE WORK OF OTHERS TO BEGIN UNDERSTANDING THE NEEDS AND STATUS OF PACIFIC LAMPREY IN THE EEL RIVER. THIS PROJECT WILL RESTART THE WIYOT TRIBES LAMPREY MONITORING PROGRAM AND INCORPORATE RECENT TECHNOLOGICAL ADVANCES TO ENSURE EFFICIENT USE OF FUNDS AND TO INFORM MANAGERS FOR EFFECTIVE ECOSYSTEM RESTORATION.

THE NORTHERN CALIFORNIA CONDOR RESTORATION PROGRAM HAS BEGUN FULL IMPLEMENTATION OF CONDOR REINTRODUCTION TONORTHERN CALIFORNIA AS OF SPRING OF 2022. ESTABLISHED IN YUROK ANCESTRAL TERRITORY AND WITHIN REDWOOD NATIONALPARK BOUNDARIES, IT REPRESENTS THE NEWEST CALIFORNIA CONDOR (CONDOR(S)) RELEASE AREA IN 19 YEARS. IT RECLAIMS ASIGNIFICANT PORTION OF CALIFORNIA CONDORS  HISTORICAL RANGE, WHICH ONCE STRETCHED FROM WHAT IS NOW BAJACALIFORNIA, MEXICO TO BRITISH COLUMBIA, CANADA. THOUGH THERE ARE MANY BENEFITS TO BE GAINED BY ESTABLISHING THISNEW SITE, IT IS FULLY EXPECTED THAT THE POPULATION WILL STRUGGLE IN THE FACE OF HUMAN IMPACTS, WHICH ARE THEPRIMARY CAUSE OF CONDORS  ENDANGERED STATUS. AFTER 40 YEARS OF CALIFORNIA CONDOR RECOVERY, MORTALITY RATESCONTINUE TO EXCEED NATURAL RECRUITMENT AND ALL SUBPOPULATIONS REMAIN DEPENDENT ON INTENSIVE MANAGEMENT AND THESUPPLEMENTATION OF CAPTIVE BRED INDIVIDUALS TO MAINTAIN POPULATION STABILITY. OVER THE PAST SEVERAL DECADES, THECALIFORNIA CONDOR RECOVERY PROGRAM, DIRECTED BY THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE, HAS FOCUSED MOST OF ITS FIELDEFFORTS, RESEARCH, AND RESOURCES TOWARD MITIGATING MORTALITY FACTORS WITHIN THE CONDOR RANGE.THE PRIMARY FACTOR PREVENTING RECOVERY OF THE CRITICALLY ENDANGERED CALIFORNIA CONDOR, AND ONE THAT ISHYPOTHESIZED TO HAVE LED TO THE SPECIES DECLINE IS LEAD TOXICOSIS RESULTING FROM INGESTION OF CARRIONCONTAMINATED WITH LEAD AMMUNITION, WHICH IS RESPONSIBLE FOR MORE THAN HALF OF ALL KNOWN CONDOR MORTALITY.ADDITIONALLY, NEW ENVIRONMENTAL CONTAMINANT THREATS ARE EMERGING FOR RAPTORS, CORVIDS, AND OBLIGATE SCAVENGERS,INCLUDING CONDORS, SUCH AS ILLEGAL PESTICIDE USE IN TRESPASS MARIJUANA GROWS RESULTING IN BOTH PRIMARY ANDSECONDARY POISONING. IT IS ESTIMATED THAT HUNDREDS OF NEW GROW SITES ARE ESTABLISHED ANNUALLY IN THE WESTERNUNITED STATES, WITH ONLY 20 40  BEING IDENTIFIED AND ADDRESSED BY LAW ENFORCEMENT. HUMBOLDT COUNTY IN CALIFORNIAIS PARTICULARLY IMPACTED BY ILLEGAL TRESPASS GROWS. AS WITH USE OF LEAD AMMUNITION, IT IS CRITICAL TO COMBINELEGAL REMEDIES WITH COMMUNITY INVESTMENT TO RAISE AWARENESS OF THE IMPACTS OF ILLEGAL RODENTICIDE USE, ANDSUPPORT PUTTING AN END TO THEIR PERSISTENCE IN THE AREA WITHIN AND SURROUNDING THE NEWLY ESTABLISHED RELEASEAREA.THE PROPOSED PROJECT WILL PROVIDE SUBSTANTIVE BENEFITS TO NORTHERN CALIFORNIA WILDLIFE AND SPECIES OF TRIBALCULTURAL IMPORTANCE, PRINCIPALLY THE CRITICALLY ENDANGERED CALIFORNIA CONDOR, THROUGH ACTIVITIES DESIGNED TOIMPROVE HABITAT CONDITIONS, REDUCE THE PREVALENCE OF ANTHROPOGENIC ENVIRONMENTAL CONTAMINANTS, AND MINIMIZEINCIDENCE OF MORTALITY. THE ULTIMATE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO EQUIP THE YUROK TRIBE AND SURROUNDING COMMUNITYWITH THE KNOWLEDGE AND CAPACITY TO REDUCE POTENTIAL IMPACTS TO CALIFORNIA CONDORS IN THE GREATER YUROK ANCESTRALREGION FROM ANTHROPOGENIC ENVIRONMENTAL CONTAMINANTS, THEREBY PROMOTING RESILIENCE WITHIN THE NORTHERN CALIFORNIACONDOR RESTORATION PROGRAM. THIS GOAL WILL BE MET VIA THREE OBJECTIVES  (1) INCREASE YUROK TRIBE WILDLIFEDEPARTMENT CAPACITY THROUGH THE DEVELOPMENT OF AN OUTREACH COORDINATOR POSITION  (2) REDUCE LEAD AMMUNITION USETHROUGH OUTREACH AND EDUCATION, THEREBY IMPROVING HABITAT CONDITIONS AND REDUCING THE POTENTIAL FOR CONDORMORTALITY  AND (3) INVESTIGATE RODENTICIDE USE IN THE PROJECT AREA AND CONDUCT OUTREACH AND EDUCATION TO REDUCEPREVALENCE. MEETING THIS GOAL WILL IMPROVE HABITAT CONDITIONS FOR WILDLIFE ON TRIBAL AND NONTRIBAL LANDS, BUILDCAPACITY AND SELF SUFFICIENCY IN TRIBAL WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT, CONTRIBUTE TO CONSERVATION OF THE CALIFORNIA CONDORWITH IMPLICATIONS FOR DOWN LISTING, ADVANCE HIGH PRIORITY TRIBAL INITIATIVES, PROMOTE INTERGOVERNMENTALMANAGEMENT OF CONDORS, AND THROUGH OUTREACH AND EDUCATION BUILD COMMUNITY CAPACITY TO SUPPORT CONDOR CONSERVATIONTHROUGH THEIR ACTIONS.

SNOQUALMIE PRAIRIE IS AN IMPORTANT TO THE SNOQUALMIE INDIAN TRIBE, BOTH FROM AN ECOLOGICAL AND CULTURAL ASPECT. TODAY, APPROXIMATELY 390 ACRES OF OPEN FORMER PRAIRIE REMAIN, IN A HIGHLY DEGRADED STATE AND FRACTURED INTO SMALLER REMNANTS. THE SNOQUALMIE PRAIRIE AREA CURRENTLY HAS APPROXIMATELY 400 ELK THAT ARE HIGHLY DEPENDENT ON OPEN MEADOWS FOR SURVIVAL. OTHER ANIMALS WELL ADAPTED TO OPEN PRAIRIES INCLUDE COYOTE, RED TAILED HAWKS, GARTER SNAKES, NORTHWESTERN SALAMANDERS, WESTERN MEADOWLARKS, WESTERN BLUEBIRDS, TOWNSENDS MOLES AND MANY OTHERS. GARRY OAKS ARE ALSO KNOWN TO SUPPORT A WIDE VARIETY OF SPECIES, AND OAK PRAIRIES ATTRACT A DISTINCT GROUP OF ANIMALS DIFFERENT FROM HARDWOOD OR CONIFER FORESTS. THE ABILITY OF THESE SPECIES TO PERSIST IN A LANDSCAPE WHERE ONLY FORESTS AND URBAN DEVELOPMENT EXIST IS QUESTIONABLE. THE REMAINING AREAS OF SNOQUALMIE PRAIRIE NEED TO NOT ONLY BE PRESERVED FROM DEVELOPMENT AND ENCROACHING FORESTS, BUT RESTORED TO FULL ECOLOGICAL CAPACITY THROUGH THE REMOVAL OF INVASIVE SPECIES AND REINTRODUCTION OF NATIVE PLANTS HISTORICALLY PRESENT. THE SNOQUALMIE INDIAN TRIBE IS PARTNERING WITH KING COUNTY PARKS, THE CITY OF SNOQUALMIE AND CITY OF NORTH BEND, AND MEADOWBROOK FARMS TO RESTORE SNOQUALMIE PRAIRIE HABITAT THROUGH RESTORATION EFFORTS. THE LARGEST CONTIGUOUS PRAIRIE REMNANT IS MEADOWBROOK FARM, AN AREA OVER 200 ACRES CONTAINING OPEN GRASSLANDS INTERSPERSED BY RIPARIAN WETLANDS ALONG KIMBALL CREEK, JOINTLY OWNED BY THE CITIES OF NORTH BEND AND SNOQUALMIE. TODAY THESE SITES REMAIN GENERALLY FREE OF TREES, DUE IN PART TO A SUSTAINED MOWING REGIMEN. THESE LANDS HOWEVER, ARE HEAVILY INFESTED BY INVASIVE PLANTS AND WEEDS, AND MANY OF THE NATIVE PLANTS HISTORICALLY CULTIVATED BY THE SNOQUALMIE TRIBE ARE NO LONGER OBSERVED. NON NATIVE PASTURE GRASSES, AS WELL AS INVASIVE REED CANARY GRASS (PHALARIS ARUNDINACEA) NOW DOMINATE LARGE SWATHS OF THE SNOQUALMIE PRAIRIE REMNANTS, WITH SEVERE INFESTATIONS OF INVASIVE HIMALAYAN BLACKBERRY (RUBUS ARMENIACUS), CANADA THISTLE (CIRSIUM ARVENSE), AND TANSY RAGWORT (JACOBAEA VULGARIS) AMONG OTHERS DISPLACING NATIVE SPECIES. SIMILARLY, GARRY OAKS NOW OCCUR ONLY VERY OCCASIONALLY AMONG THE SNOQUALMIE PRAIRIE REMNANTS, WITH JUST A SMALL NUMBER OF INDIVIDUAL MATURE TREES KNOWN. THE ECOLOGICAL RESTORATION OF SNOQUALMIE PRAIRIE REMNANTS WILL REQUIRE A CONCERTED EFFORT OVER MANY YEARS. EVEN AFTER INITIAL WEED CONTROL AND PLANTING, MAINTENANCE WILL BE NECESSARY INDEFINITELY TO MAINTAIN ESTABLISHED POPULATIONS OF NATIVE MEADOW SPECIES AND REMOVE INVASIVE PLANTS. THE FIRST PHASE OF THE PROJECT WILL BE A PILOT HABITAT RESTORATION PROJECT USING PRIMARY RESTORATION ACTIVITIES  (1) THE RESTORATION OF APPROXIMATELY 3.5 ACRES OF NATIVE GARRY OAK MEADOW  (2) A TOTAL OF APPROXIMATELY 1.8 ACRES OF NATIVE MEADOW GRASSES AND FORBS INSTALLED  (3) REMOVAL OF INVASIVE SPECIES FROM APPROXIMATELY 2 ACRES  (4) CRITICAL DATA FOR SUCCESSFULLY EXPANDING MEADOW RESTORATION TO DOZENS OF ACRES OR MORE IN LATER PROJECT PHASES  (5) PROVIDING A BLUEPRINT FOR PRESERVING IMPORTANT AND RARE MEADOW HABITAT CRITICAL TO THE FULLY FUNCTIONING LANDSCAPE MOSAIC OF THE REGION  (6) THE PRESERVATION OF OPEN MEADOW HABITAT CRITICAL TO ELK AND MANY OTHER SPECIES, AND (7) AN OPPORTUNITY FOR TRIBAL MEMBERS AND COMMUNITY MEMBERS TO DIRECTLY ENGAGE IN RESTORING A LANDSCAPE OF GREAT CULTURAL IMPORTANCE TO THE SNOQUALMIE TRIBE.

THIS GRANT MANAGES BEAVERS AND ROAD CONFLICTS ON TRIBAL LANDS THAT HAVE ECONOMIC, CULTURAL, AND BIOLOGICAL IMPACTS THAT NEEDS TO BE ADDRESSED WITH LONG TERM SOLUTIONS. THIS PROPOSAL WILL FUND THE CONSTRUCTION OF 10 WATER CONTROL DEVICES BUILT OVER 2 SUMMERS BY DEPARTMENT STAFF AND SUMMER TRIBAL YOUTH.

TRIBAL WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT CAN BE A COMPLICATED PROCESS, OFTEN REQUIRING DANGEROUS METHODS AND THE NAVIGATION OF COMPLEX CULTURAL AND SOCIO POLITICAL ENVIRONMENTS. MANY TRADITIONAL WILDLIFE SAMPLING TECHNIQUES RELY ON INVASIVE SAMPLING THAT CAN BE DANGEROUS TO ANIMALS AND BIOLOGISTS BUT CAN ALSO COME INTO CONFLICT WITH CULTURAL AND POLITICAL ASPECTS OF THE TRIBAL ENVIRONMENT, SUCH AS PRIVATE LAND SECURITY AND SOCIO POLITICAL ISSUES SURROUNDING WILDLIFE. FOR EXAMPLE, CHEMICAL IMMOBILIZATION DRUGS CAN BE DANGEROUS TO BIOLOGISTS OR FOCAL ANIMALS BUT ARE NECESSARY TO TAG AND TRACK ANIMALS FOR UNDERSTANDING POPULATION INFORMATION. IN ADDITION, BECAUSE MANY ANIMALS ARE CULTURALLY REVERED OR CONSUMED, CHEMICAL IMMOBILIZATION IS UNWANTED BY THE COMMUNITY BECAUSE OF ITS POTENTIAL HARM TO THE ANIMAL OR TRANSFER TO PEOPLE. VOLUNTEER HARVEST SUBMISSIONS HAVE ALSO BEEN DIFFICULT TO OBTAIN DUE TO THE PRIVATE NATURE OF THE CHEROKEE CULTURE. HOWEVER, THERE ARE NON INVASIVE SAMPLING TECHNIQUES AND NOVEL ANALYSIS METHODS NOW AVAILABLE THAT CAN PROVIDE SOME OF THE SAME TYPES OF DATA AS INVASIVE SAMPLING TECHNIQUES WHILE ENSURING SAFETY AND SOCIO POLITICAL ISSUES REMAIN UNDISTURBED. THE EASTERN BAND OF CHEROKEE INDIANS OFFICE OF FISHERIES AND WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT PROPOSES TO DEVELOP SEVERAL NON INVASIVE TECHNIQUES TO WORK TOWARDS ANSWERING SOME OF THE SAME QUESTIONS INVASIVE SAMPLING WOULD ANSWER. WE HAVE CATEGORIZED THESE TECHNIQUES INTO MOLECULAR AND TECHNOLOGICAL. SOME NON INVASIVE MOLECULAR SAMPLING TECHNIQUES INCLUDE  DNA SAMPLING IN STREAMS AND BOGS FOR RARE FISH, HELLBENDER SALAMANDERS AND BOG TURTLES, HAIR SNARES FOR BEAR POPULATION DYNAMICS, ASSESSMENT OF BEAR NUISANCE ISSUES FROM SWABBING, FOR FECAL MARK RECAPTURE OF FLYING SQUIRRELS AND BATS  ENVIRONMENTAL DNA FOR DETECTION OF AQUATIC SPECIES LIKE SICKLEFIN REDHORSE AND HELLBENDER SALAMANDERS  HAIR SNARES FOR AMERICAN BLACK BEARS, AND FORENSIC ANALYSIS OF BEAR HUMAN CONFLICT AREAS. OUR TECHNOLOGICAL METHODS INCLUDE  CAMERA TRAP SAMPLING FOR GAME SPECIES (I.E. BEARS, WILD HOGS, COYOTES, BOBCATS, TURKEY. GROUSE) AND NON GAME RARE OR PROTECTED SPECIES (I.E. CAROLINA NORTHERN FLYING SQUIRRELS, SPOTTED SKUNKS, ARMADILLOS, ELK, DEER)  AND ACOUSTIC SAMPLING FOR BATS, BIRDS AND AMPHIBIANS. ADDITIONALLY, WE ARE ADDING GUIDED CAMERA SURVEYS SUCH AS UNDERWATER PROBES FOR HELLBENDERS AND DRONE SAMPLING FOR HABITAT EVALUATION AND SEARCHING FOR ELK CALVES IN REMOTE AREAS. NON INVASIVE SAMPLING HAS LOW IMPACTS BUT REQUIRES CONSIDERABLE TRAINING IN METHODS DEPLOYMENT, DATA MANAGEMENT AND SEVERAL HIGH LEVEL ANALYSIS TECHNIQUES. TO ACCOMPLISH THESE GOALS, WILL REQUIRE FUNDING FOR CONTRACTUAL SAMPLING, EQUIPMENT, SUPPLIES, TRAVEL, AND TRAINING. THESE TOOLS AND PROCESSES WILL NOT ONLY HELP US UNDERSTAND NEEDS TO PROTECT AND RESTORE IMPORTANT SPECIES, THEY WILL HELP THE CHEROKEE COMMUNITY, UNDER FEDERAL REGULATORY NEEDS, MAINTAIN ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL INDEPENDENCE AS A SOVEREIGN NATION.

THE BAD RIVER BAND OF THE LAKE SUPERIOR TRIBE OF CHIPPEWA INDIANS IS LOCATED ON 125,000  ACRES, PRIMARILY LOWLANDS, IN RURAL NORTHERN WISCONSIN ALONG 36 MILES OF THE SOUTHERN SHORELINE OF GICHIGUMI (LAKE SUPERIOR). THE INTERIOR WETLANDS OF THE BAD RIVER RESERVATION, WHICH MAKE UP MUCH OF THE SURFACE AREA OF THE RESERVATION, HISTORICALLY HAVE BEEN UNDER STUDIED BY THE MASHKIIZIIBII (BAD RIVER) NATURAL RESOURCES DEPARTMENT (MNRD) WILDLIFE PROGRAM WHEN COMPARED TO THE FRESHWATER ESTUARIES. BECAUSE OF THE RELATIVE LACK OF PAST STUDY, AND BECAUSE THESE OPEN WATER WETLANDS ARE INTEGRAL OVER THE LIFESPANS OF MOST OF THE KNOWN WILDLIFE SPECIES IN THE AREA, THE BAD RIVER BAND HAS IDENTIFIED WETLANDS AS A PRIORITIZED RESOURCE OF CONCERN IN ITS SEVENTH GENERATION CLIMATE CHANGE MONITORING PLAN (2016).  THE SITES SELECTED FOR THIS STUDY WERE CHOSEN AS THEY ARE REPRESENTATIVE OF MANY OF THE INTERIOR WETLANDS WITHIN BAD RIVER, AND FOR THEIR ACCESSIBILITY. FIVE OF THE EIGHT WETLANDS SITES ARE AMIK CREATED (BEAVER, CASTOR CANADENSIS) WETLANDS.  THESE WETLANDS FOSTER DIVERSE FLORAL AND FAUNAL LIFE  BEAVER LODGES PROVIDE SHELTER TO NUMEROUS OTHER SPECIES IN THE WINTER AND BEAVER DAMS SERVE AS CORRIDORS FOR SPECIES SUCH AS WAAWAASHKESHI (WHITE TAILED DEER  ODOCOILEUS VIRGINIANUS) AND MAIINGAN (GRAY WOLF  CANIS LUPUS).OBJECTIVES OF THE PROGRAM ARE TO  1.) CONDUCT THREE INVESTIGATIONS FOR EACH OF EIGHT INTERIOR OPEN WATER WETLANDS WITHIN THE BAD RIVER RESERVATION BY COLLECTING AND ANALYZING DATA TO ESTABLISH MEASURES OF BASELINE DIVERSITY FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE SPECIES WITHIN EACH IDENTIFIED OPEN WATER WETLANDS  2.) CONDUCT THREE INVESTIGATIONS FOR EACH OF EIGHT INTERIOR OPEN WATER WETLANDS BY COLLECTING AND ANALYZING DATA TO SURVEY CULTURAL AND PROTECTED FISH AND WILDLIFE SPECIES WITHIN EACH IDENTIFIED OPEN WATER WETLANDS  3.) CONDUCT THREE INVESTIGATIONS FOR EACH OF EIGHT INTERIOR OPEN WATER WETLANDS BY COLLECTING AND ANALYZING DATA FOCUSED ON FISH AND WILDLIFE HABITATS IN THE IDENTIFIED OPEN WATER WETLANDS, WITH SPECIFIC EMPHASIS ON PLANT DIVERSITY AS WELL AS CULTURAL AND PROTECTED PLANT SPECIES  4.) PRODUCE ONE PRODUCT BY CREATING AN HERBARIUM OF AT LEAST ONE REPRESENTATIVE FOR EACH MAJOR TAXONOMIC GROUP FOUND IN THE EIGHT IDENTIFIED WETLANDS TO BE USED FOR OUTREACH AT EVENTS PROVIDING EDUCATION ABOUT NATIVE PLANTS TO THE AREA  AND 5.) PARTICIPATE IN OR SPONSOR THREE EVENTS.A GOAL OF THE PROGRAM IS FOR RESEARCHERS TO CREATE AN INDEX OF BIOLOGICAL INTEGRITY (IBI) FOR EACH WETLAND TO DETERMINE WETLAND HEALTH AND PRIORITIZE RESTORATIVE ACTIONS IF NEEDED.THE OVERALL OUTCOME IS FOR THE BAD RIVER BAND TO HAVE ACCURATE DATA TO MAKE MANAGEMENT DECISIONS THAT WILL BEST PROTECT AND ENHANCE RESILIENCY OF ITS INTERIOR WETLANDS AND THE PLANT LIFE AND WILDLIFE THAT DEPEND UPON THEM.

PORT GRAHAM VILLAGE COUNCIL IS REQUESTING  139,946.00 IN TRIBAL WILDLIFE GRANTS TO FUND THE  MOOSE COMPOSITION OF THE SOUTHERN KENAI PENINSULA  A COLLABORATIVE EFFORT  PROJECT. MOOSE ARE A PRIORITY SPECIES TO MANY SUBSISTENCE COMMUNITIES AS A PRIMARY SOURCE OF FOOD THAT MAY BE HARVESTED ON MOST LANDS IN ALASKA, IN ADDITION TO BEING HARVESTED BY THE GENERAL PUBLIC. MOOSE ARE THE MOST IMPORTANT UNGULATE HARVESTED IN THE LOWER COOK INLET AND THE DEMAND IS INCREASING AS THE HUMAN POPULATION GROWS IN AND AROUND THE REGION. OVER THE PAST SEVERAL YEARS, TRIBAL MEMBERS HAVE EXPRESSED CONCERN ABOUT MOOSE POPULATIONS AND CONTINUITY OF A SUBSISTENCE LIFESTYLE, INCLUDING SPECIES HEALTH, IMPACTS OF CHANGING ENVIRONMENTAL CLIMATE CONDITIONS, AND RESOURCE COMPETITION INTERFERENCE WITH COMMERCIAL AND SUBSISTENCE FISHERIES. EFFECTIVE AND RESPONSIBLE MANAGEMENT OF CARE OF OUR FISH AND WILDLIFE IN ALASKA REQUIRES MEANINGFUL COMMUNICATION AND COLLABORATION BETWEEN THE STATE AND TRIBAL PARTNERS. WHEN MISMANAGED, REGULATIONS RESTRICT PEOPLE FROM PRACTICING CULTURAL WAYS OF LIFE, THEY LOSE PIECES OF WHO THEY ARE. THESE HARDSHIPS ESPECIALLY AFFECT CHILDREN AND ELDERS.  THROUGH A PARTNERSHIP WITH CRRC AND ADFAND G, THIS PROJECT WILL WORK TOWARDS BUILDING CAPACITY TOWARDS TRIBAL SELF SUFFICIENCY IN RESOURCE MANAGEMENT, UPDATING POPULATION AND COMPOSITION ESTIMATE DATA OF THE MOOSE IN THE LOWER COOK INLET, COMPLETE ETHNOGRAPHIC INTERVIEWS FOCUSED ON TRADITIONAL ECOLOGICAL KNOWLEDGE, AND ADDRESS TRIBAL CONCERNS OVER MOOSE DATA GAPS IN THE LOWER COOK INLET. THIS PROJECT WILL WORK TOWARDS THE FOLLOWING OBJECTIVES  1) BY THE END OF JANUARY 2023, PORT GRAHAM VILLAGE COUNCIL (THROUGH CRRC) WILL HAVE LOCAL PORT GRAHAM FIELD TECHNICIANS AND CONTRACT STAFF WITH ADFAND G SECURED AND FIELD TRAINING HAS BEGUN. 2) BY THE END OF DECEMBER 2023, PORT GRAHAM VILLAGE COUNCIL (THROUGH CRRC) WILL HAVE CONDUCTED 1 AERIAL MOOSE COMPOSITION SURVEY. 3) BY THE END OF AUGUST 2024, PORT GRAHAM VILLAGE COUNCIL (THROUGH CRRC AND ADFAND G) WILL HAVE DEVELOPED AN ALTERNATIVE MOOSE MONITORING PROGRAM. 4)BY THE END OF AUGUST 2024, PORT GRAHAM VILLAGE COUNCIL (THROUGH CRRC AND ADFAND G) WILL HAVE CONDUCTED AND COMPLETED FOCUS GROUP INTERVIEWS WITH PORT GRAHAM RESIDENTS AND HAVE ANALYZED THE DATA INTO A REPORT. 5) BY THE END OF DECEMBER 2024, PORT GRAHAM VILLAGE COUNCIL (THROUGH CRRC) WILL COMPLETE A REPORT DETAILING ALL RESULTS FROM THE MOOSE SURVEYS AND FOCUS GROUP INTERVIEWS. WE EXPECT THE OBJECTIVES OF THIS PROJECT TO LEAD TO THE FOLLOWING RESULTS AND BENEFITS  1) THE TRIBAL CAPACITY TO MANAGE NATURAL RESOURCES SELF SUFFICIENTLY AND IN PARTNERSHIP WITH OTHER AGENCIES AND DECISION MAKING ORGANIZATIONS. 2) UPDATED POPULATION ESTIMATES, DENSITY, BULL COW AND CALF COW RATIO, AND TREND DATA FOR THE MOOSE IN THE LOWER COOK INLET THAT WILL AID MANAGERS OF THIS REGION IN MAKING INFORMED DECISIONS. 3 ) DETERMINATING ANY HIGH QUALITY MOOSE HABITATS IN THE SURVEY AREA TO HELP THE TRIBE LEAD EFFECTIVE CONSERVATION EFFORTS FOR MOOSE HABITATS IN THE REGION. 4) THE CONTINUATION OF MOOSE POPULATION MONITORING IN THE LOWER COOK INLET. 5) THE COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS OF ACCURATE AND PRECISE MOOSE POPULATION AND COMPOSITION DATA THAT CAN ADDRESS THE TRIBE S CONCERNS OVER THE MOOSE POPULATION AND ALLOW FOR THE ADFAND G TO MANAGE THE POPULATION AND MAKE SOUND DECISIONS FOR SUBSISTENCE ORDINANCES. 6) USING THE DATA COLLECTED DURING THIS PROJECT TO ASSIST IN GAINING A POSITIVE CAND T FOR NANWALEK AND PORT GRAHAM.
THIS GRANT WILL RESTORE 1.5 MILES ALONG THE MAINSTEM OF THE MEDUXNEKEAG RIVER WITH A FOCUS ON SUSTENANCE FISHING AND WILL BENIFIT ALL PEOPLE.

IN THIS PROJECT, THE NEZ PERCE TRIBE (TRIBE) DEPARTMENT OF FISHERIES RESOURCES MANAGEMENT (DFRM) WILL EVALUATE CRITICAL UNCERTAINTIES RELATED TO THE REINTRODUCTION OF SOCKEYE SALMON TO WALLOWA LAKE, OREGON. SOCKEYE SALMON WERE EXTIRPATED FROM WALLOWA LAKE IN THE EARLY 1900S. RESTORING THESE FISH TO WALLOWA LAKE AND THE ANCESTRAL LANDS OF THE TRIBE IS OF DEEP IMPORTANCE. DFRM HAS BEEN INVOLVED WITH REINTRODUCTION EFFORTS SINCE THE 1990S. PROGRESS TOWARD REINTRODUCTION HAS BEEN CHALLENGING, BUT THE POTENTIAL FOR A FULL REINTRODUCTION IS BECOMING A REALITY DUE TO A NUMBER OF RECENT EVENTS, INCLUDING FUNDING APPROVAL FOR THE RECONSTRUCTION OF WALLOWA LAKE DAM. RENOVATING THE DAM WILL RESTORE FISH PASSAGE TO AND FROM THE LAKE. HOWEVER, IMPORTANT INFORMATION GAPS REMAIN THAT MAY REDUCE THE CHANCES OF A SUCCESSFUL REINTRODUCTION. IN THIS PROJECT, WE WILL THOROUGHLY RESEARCH FOUR CRITICAL INFORMATION GAPS  1) MIGRATION CORRIDOR CONDITIONS FOR ADULT AND JUVENILE SOCKEYE SALMON  2) IMPACTS OF NON NATIVE SPECIES IN WALLOWA LAKE  3) EFFECTS OF LAKE PRODUCTIVITY ON JUVENILE SOCKEYE GROWTH AND RECRUITMENT  AND 4) EVALUATION OF EXISTING SPAWNING HABITAT IN THE LAKE AND ITS TRIBUTARIES. THIS PROJECT WILL COMPILE A COMBINATION OF EXISTING DATA, COLLECT NEW DATA IN THE FIELD AND LABORATORY, AND ANALYZE AND SUMMARIZE INFORMATION LEARNED FOR EACH OF THE FOUR CRITICAL INFORMATION GAPS. RESULTS WILL DISSEMINATED DIRECTLY TO RESOURCE MANAGERS AND PROVIDE A BASELINE FOR FUTURE ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT. THE PROPOSED RESEARCH AND PLANNING WILL SIGNIFICANTLY AID THE TRIBE IN ACCOMPLISHING THEIR LONG TERM GOAL OF RETURNING A POPULATION OF SOCKEYE SALMON TO WALLOWA LAKE.

THE PEOPLE OF THE PUEBLO OF SANTA ANA HAVE LIVED ALONG THE BANKS OF THE RIO GRANDE AND RIO JEMEZ FOR OVER 400 YEARS. THEY HAVE ENDURED THROUGH THE CENTURIES BY MAINTAINING THEIR TRADITIONAL, CULTURAL, AND SPIRITUAL WAYS THAT ARE STRONGLY INFLUENCE BY THEIR CONNECTION TO THE NATURAL WORLD. LIKE MANY OTHER TRIBES, THIS CONNECTION INVOLVES THE USE OF TRADITIONALLY IMPORTANT UNGULATE SPECIES SUCH AS MULE DEER, ROCKY MOUNTAIN ELK, AND PRONGHORN. BECAUSE THESE SPECIES HAVE SIGNIFICANT CULTURAL AND SPIRITUAL RELEVANCE, IT IS IMPORTANT TO THE PUEBLO TO ENSURE SUSTAINABLE POPULATIONS ON THEIR LANDS FOR CURRENT AND FUTURE GENERATIONS. A CHALLENGE TO THIS, IS BALANCING THE PREDATOR PREY RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN AN INCREASING MOUNTAIN LION POPULATION AND LOW DENSITY, ISOLATED UNGULATE POPULATIONS. ANOTHER CHALLENGE IS THAT, LIKE UNGULATES, MOUNTAIN LIONS ARE ALSO A TRADITIONALLY IMPORTANT SPECIES, SO SIMPLY REMOVING ALL LIONS FROM THE PUEBLO IS NOT AN ACCEPTABLE SOLUTION. IT IS CLEAR TO THE PUEBLO, THAT TO INCREASE UNGULATE POPULATIONS ON ITS LAND, IT MUST INCREASE ITS UNGULATE REPRODUCTION POTENTIAL BY PROTECTING BOTH ADULT AND NEONATE UNGULATES FROM MOUNTAIN LION PREDATION AND IDENTIFY AND PROTECT CORRIDORS USED BY UNGULATES TO MEET THEIR ANNUAL NEEDS, OR FOR DISPERSAL OR IMMIGRATION ONTO THE PUEBLO. BECAUSE REMOVING MOUNTAIN LIONS THAT DEMONSTRATE A PROPENSITY TO SELECT UNGULATE SPECIES AS PREY HAS BEEN SHOWN TO INCREASE LOW DENSITY UNGULATE POPULATIONS, THE PUEBLO NEEDS TO BETTER UNDERSTAND WHICH LIONS ARE SELECTING UNGULATES SO THAT IT CAN PRESENT THIS INFORMATION TO THE TRIBAL COUNCIL AND TRADITIONAL LEADERS FOR THEM TO MAKE INFORMED MANAGEMENT DECISIONS REGARDING THE FATE OF SUCH INDIVIDUAL LIONS. HOWEVER, BEFORE THIS CAN HAPPEN, PREDATION DATA WILL NEED TO BE COLLECTED TO IDENTIFY THE INDIVIDUAL LIONS THAT ARE NEGATIVELY IMPACTING UNGULATE POPULATIONS. THEREFORE, THE PUEBLO IS PROPOSING TO CAPTURE AND GPS COLLAR SIX MOUNTAIN LIONS, MONITOR PREDATION EVENTS AND IDENTIFY PREY SPECIES KILLED BY COLLARED LIONS, AND MONITOR MOUNTAIN LION MOVEMENTS TO IDENTIFY THE LOCATIONS OF WILDLIFE CORRIDORS. THE PROPOSED PROJECT HAS THE FULL SUPPORT OF THE PUEBLO S TRIBAL COUNCIL AND IS IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY NEW MEXICO COOPERATIVE FISH AND WILDLIFE RESEARCH UNIT, NEW MEXICO DEPARTMENT OF GAME AND FISH, AND THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE VALLES CALDERA NATIONAL PRESERVE. FURTHERMORE, THE PROPOSED PROJECT INVOLVES BUILDING THE PUEBLO S CAPACITY TO PROVIDE FOR THE BENEFIT AND PROTECTION OF WILDLIFE AND EDUCATE THE COMMUNITY ABOUT MOUNTAIN LIONS ON THEIR LAND. LASTLY, THE PROPOSED PROJECT WILL CONTRIBUTE TO IMPROVING LOCAL AND REGIONAL MANAGEMENT PLANS FOR MOUNTAIN LION AND UNGULATES BY CONTRIBUTING SCIENCE BASED INFORMATION ON KILL RATES AND PREY COMPOSITION OF MOUNTAIN LIONS IN NEW MEXICO.

MANY AREAS IN SOUTHEAST ALASKA HAVE BEEN SURVEYED FOR INVASIVE SPECIES, HABITATS HAVE BEEN RESTORED, AND MONITORING HAS AND CONTINUES TO OCCUR, HOWEVER, NATIVE ALLOTMENTS IN SOUTHEAST ALASKA HAVE BEEN LARGELY UNOBSERVED AND UNMONITORED. THESE NATIVE ALLOTMENTS SPATIALLY POSSESS BOTH HISTORICAL AND CULTURAL SIGNIFICANCE. A LARGE SECTOR OF OUR CULTURAL AND NATURAL RESOURCES IS BEING THREATENED BY INVASIVE SPECIES AND A RAPIDLY CHANGING CLIMATE. THE RESEARCH CONDUCTED IN THE INVASIVE SPECIES ON NATIVE ALLOTMENTS IN SOUTHEAST ALASKA MANAGEMENT PLAN WILL  OBTAIN AN ACCURATE SCOPE OF THE INVASIVE AND RECOLONIZING SPECIES ON NATIVE ALLOTMENT LANDS, CREATE AN INVASIVE SPECIES ON NATIVE ALLOTMENTS REPORT AND AN INVASIVE SPECIES ON NATIVE ALLOTMENTS MANAGEMENT PLAN, AND ULTIMATELY CONDUCT HABITAT RESTORATION TO THE EXTENT POSSIBLE. THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS A HEALTHIER SOUTHEAST ALASKA BY CONDUCTING RESEARCH, SPATIAL ANALYSIS, MANAGEMENT PLANNING, HABITAT RESTORATION, AND REPORTING ON INVASIVE SPECIES ON NATIVE ALLOTMENTS IN SOUTHEAST ALASKA.

THE ALEUT COMMUNITY OF ST. PAUL ISLAND (ACSPI) TRIBAL GOVERNMENT HAS BEEN A LEADER IN THE MOVEMENT BY ALASKA NATIVE ENTITIES TO BECOME MORE EQUITABLE PARTICIPANTS IN THE MANAGEMENT AND CONSERVATION OF THEIR LANDS AND RESOURCES. IN RESPONSE TO RAPID ENVIRONMENTAL CHANGES IN THE BERING SEA ECOSYSTEM, ACSPI LAUNCHED THE PRIBILOF ISLANDS MARINE ECOSYSTEM (PRIME) INITIATIVE, WITH THE NOMINATION OF ALAGUM KANUUX, OR THE HEART OF THE OCEAN IN UNANGAN TUNUU, TO BE DESIGNATED AS A UNIQUE NATIONAL MARINE SANCTUARY. PRIME IS A NEW SANCTUARY MODEL THAT IS USING A NEW APPROACH TO CREATE EQUITABLE, TRIBAL LED CO MANAGEMENT FOR ONE OF THE WORLDS MOST IMPORTANT AND SENSITIVE MARINE AREAS  THE SOUTHEASTERN SECTOR OF THE BERING SEA. A CRITICAL PILLAR OF PRIME IS TO PROMOTE TRIBAL LED RESEARCH AND COLLABORATIONS TO INCORPORATE AN INCLUSIVE UNDERSTANDING OF PRIME, GROUNDED IN INDIGENOUS, TRADITIONAL AND LOCAL KNOWLEDGE AND EMPIRICAL SCIENCE. DRIVING THE DESIRE TO CONDUCT RESEARCH AND OF PARTICULAR CONCERN IS THAT SEA ICE EXTENT FOR THE BERING SEA REGION REACHED RECORD LOWS IN 2018 AND 2019, WHICH WAS PRECEDED BY SEVERAL YEARS OF PROFOUND ENVIRONMENTAL CHANGES ACROSS ALASKA RANGING FROM RECORD AIR AND OCEAN TEMPERATURE INCREASES, REDUCTIONS IN SNOW COVER AND SEA ICE SEASONS, AND INCREASES IN RAINFALL, TO MASS MORTALITY EVENTS FOR MARINE ANIMALS INCLUDING SEABIRDS OF THE BERING SEA REGION. CENTRAL TO UNDERSTANDING THE POTENTIAL IMPACTS FROM OCEAN CLIMATE VARIABILITY, HARMFUL ALGAL BLOOMS (HABS), AND OCEAN ACIDIFICATION, IS A QUANTITATIVE UNDERSTANDING OF THE PELAGIC DISTRIBUTIONS, PHENOLOGY OF MIGRATORY AND WINTERING PERIODS, ENVIRONMENTAL CORRELATES OF SEABIRD MOVEMENTS DURING THE NON BREEDING SEASON, AND IF AND HOW SEABIRD MARINE HABITAT USE HAS CHANGED IN RECENT YEARS IN RESPONSE TO THE SIGNIFICANT RECENT ENVIRONMENTAL CHANGES OBSERVED FOR THE BERING SEA ECOSYSTEM. TO THIS END, WE PROPOSE TO QUANTIFY NON BREEDING MARINE DISTRIBUTIONS, PHENOLOGY OF THE MIGRATORY AND WINTERING PERIODS, AND ASSOCIATIONS WITH ENVIRONMENTAL FEATURES FOR TWO KEY SEABIRD SPECIES THAT ARE IMPORTANT CULTURAL AND ECOLOGICAL COMPONENTS OF THE AVIFAUNA THAT NEST AT ST. PAUL ISLAND, ALASKA  BLACK LEGGED KITTIWAKES (RISSA TRIDACTYLA) AND THICK BILLED MURRES (URIA LOMVIA)  TO ADDRESS THE FOLLOWING OBJECTIVES  (1) QUANTIFY THEIR SPATIAL AND TEMPORAL PELAGIC MOVEMENTS DURING NON BREEDING SEASON USING LIGHT LEVEL GEOLOCATION  (2) CALCULATE SEX SPECIFIC, SEASONAL UTILIZATION DISTRIBUTIONS  (3) EXAMINE THEIR OCEANIC HABITAT USE DURING NON BREEDING SEASON IN RELATION TO IN SITU AND REMOTELY SENSED PHYSICAL AND BIOLOGICAL ENVIRONMENTAL COVARIATES  (4) DETERMINE THE OVERLAP OF THE PRIME INITIATIVES CORE REGION, WITH SEASONAL UTILIZATION DISTRIBUTIONS  AND (5) TRAIN THE NEXT GENERATION OF SEABIRD ECOLOGISTS, AND CONDUCT DATA SCIENCE FOCUSED OUTREACH EVENTS TO ST. PAUL ISLAND STUDENTS AND OTHER STUDENTS. THIS PROJECT IS EXEMPLARY IN THAT IT FOSTERS RESEARCH COLLABORATIONS BETWEEN ACSPI, US FEDERAL AGENCIES, ACADEMIC RESEARCH INSTITUTIONS, AND NON PROFITS, CREATING KNOWLEDGE AND EDUCATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES THAT WILL BE CRITICAL FOR THE RESPONSIBLE MANAGEMENT OF THE PRIME NOW AND IN THE FUTURE. THE FINAL PRODUCTS OF THE PROPOSED RESEARCH WILL HAVE KEY MANAGEMENT IMPLICATIONS AND WILL PROVIDE A COMPREHENSIVE UNDERSTANDING OF THE MARINE WATERS USED BY THESE SEABIRD SPECIES OUTSIDE THE BREEDING SEASON, WHICH CAN INFORM SPATIAL PROTECTIONS WITHIN THE CONTEXT OF PRIME AND HIGHLIGHT REGIONS OUTSIDE THE PRIME CORE REGION USED BY THESE SPECIES TO UNDERSTAND POTENTIAL INTERACTIONS WITH FISHERIES, POLLUTION, AND OCEAN CLIMATE VARIABILITY. THE ESTABLISHMENT OF ALAGUM KANUUX WILL ALLOW CONSERVATION ACTIONS TO FOLLOW THE LEADS OF ST. PAUL ISLAND AND ENSURE THAT TRIBAL CO MANAGEMENT IS A CENTRAL FEATURE IN THE FUTURE OF THE PRIBILOF ISLANDS MARINE ECOSYSTEM THROUGH THE RESPONSIBLE CO MANAGEMENT OF CULTURAL KEYSTONE SPECIES.

TYONEK TRIBAL CONSERVATION DISTRICT OF WEST COOK INLET, ALASKA, SEEKS TO RESTORE, ENHANCE, AND PROTECT FRESHWATER SYSTEMS AND SUBSISTENCE SALMON RESOURCES IMPORTANT TO THE NATIVE VILLAGE OFTYONEK, A FEDERALLY RECOGNIZED TRIBE. SALMON (ONCORHYNCHUS SPP.), AND PARTICULARLY CHINOOK SALMON (ONCORHYNCHUS TSHAWYTSCHA), ARE NOT ONLY A VITAL FOOD RESOURCE FOR THE PEOPLE OF TYONEK,(THE TEBUGHNA, OR  BEACH  PEOPLE), BUT SERVE AN IMPORTANT CULTURAL AND TRADITIONAL ROLE WITHIN THE COMMUNITY. COOK INLET CHINOOK SALMON HAVE BEEN IN DECLINE OVER THE PAST DECADE, RESULTING IN LOWER PROPORTIONS OF CHINOOK BEING CAUGHT IN TYONEK SUBSISTENCE SETNETS. THE WEST, SUSITNA, ANDYENTNA AREAS OF WEST COOK INLET PROVIDE IMPORTANT SPAWNING AND REARING HABITAT FOR MANY OF THE CHINOOK SALMON DESTINED FOR TYONEK SETNETS, YET WATER TEMPERATURE, FLOW, AND HABITAT DATA IS SPARSE FOR THIS LARGE, REMOTE REGION. WITH ONGOING WARMING AIR AND WATER TEMPERATURES, ALTERED FLOW REGIMES, DOCUMENTED VEGETATION SHIFTS, AND INVASIONS OF NORTHERN PIKE (ESOX LUCIUS) AND THE AQUATIC INVASIVE PLANT ELODEA CANADENSIS IN SOUTHCENTRAL ALASKA, ESTABLISHING A BASELINE FOR IMPORTANT SPAWNING AND REARING LOCATIONS IS CRITICAL AND HELPS TO IDENTIFY AREAS OF HIGH QUALITY HABITAT FOR CONSERVATION EFFORTS. MUCH OF THE TYONEK SUBSISTENCE CHINOOK SALMON IMPORTANT SALMON SPAWNING AND REARING HABITAT FALLS WITHIN THE BOUNDARIES OF THE 6.6 MILLION ACRE TYONEK TRIBAL CONSERVATION DISTRICT (TTCD).TTCD CURRENTLY MONITORS FRESHWATER STREAM HABITAT WITHIN THE SMALLER TYONEK AREA WATERSHED DIRECTLY SURROUNDING THE COMMUNITY, AND THIS PROJECT WILL EXPAND TTCD S SCOPE BEYOND THE IMMEDIATE TYONEK WATERSHED TO COLLECT AND ANALYZE WATER QUALITY, TEMPERATURE, WATER FLOW, FISH,AND HABITAT DATA ON STREAMS IMPORTANT FOR CHINOOK SALMON SPAWNING AND REARING ACROSS THE DISTRICT. THIS TWO YEAR PROJECT WILL IDENTIFY PRIORITY WATERSHED AND AQUATIC RESOURCE ISSUES, KEY HABITATS WITHIN DISTINCT AQUATIC SYSTEMS, ESTABLISH BASELINE WATER QUALITY, TEMPERATURE, AND FLOW MONITORING ON A TOTAL OF 8 FRESHWATER SYSTEMS IMPORTANT FOR CHINOOK SALMON SPAWNING AND REARING WITHIN THE DISTRICT, COMPLETE A COMPREHENSIVE OVERVIEW OF FRESHWATER STREAM RESOURCES OF THE TYONEK TRIBAL CONSERVATION DISTRICT, INCREASE THE NATIVE VILLAGE OF TYONEK S CAPACITY TO COLLECT AQUATIC DATA AND MANAGE THEIR FRESHWATER RESOURCES, AND DISSEMINATE DATA IN A WIDELY ACCESSIBLE MANNER USING MEETINGS, CONFERENCES, AND WEB BASED DATA SHARING.

THE QAWALANGIN TRIBE OF UNALASKA IS A FEDERALLY RECOGNIZED TRIBE LOCATED IN THE ALEUTIAN CHAIN ON THE ISLAND OF UNALASKA, WHICH RELIES ON SHELLFISH AS A SUBSISTENCE FOOD. BLUE MUSSELS ARE OF TRADITIONAL AND CULTURAL IMPORTANCE AS IT HAS BEEN A TRIBAL FOOD SOURCE FOR OVER 8,000 YEARS.CLIMATE CHANGE HAS CAUSED AN INCREASE IN THE FREQUENCY AND OCCURRENCE OF ALGAE BLOOMS, WHICH HAS RESULTED IN A DECREASE IN BLUE MUSSEL HABITAT QUALITY AND INCREASED THE PSP IN MUSSELS. THESE IMPACTS, IN TURN, ARE THREATENING THE LIVELIHOOD, FOOD SECURITY, AND CULTURAL TRADITIONS OF THE TRIBE AND RESULTED IN AT LEAST ONE DEATH. THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO DEVELOP A NATURAL RESOURCES CONSERVATION PLAN (NRCP) TO RESTORE THE BLUE MUSSEL HABITAT WITHIN UNALASKA BAY TO INCREASE CULTURAL AND TRIBAL SUBSISTENCE FOOD SECURITY, REDUCE PSP POISONING IN WILDLIFE AND PEOPLE, AND IMPLEMENT A NATURE BASED TECHNIQUE FOR IMPROVING WATER QUALITY AND AQUATIC ECOSYSTEM HEALTH.

THE NATIVE VILLAGE OF EKLUTNA (NVE) PROPOSES TO CONTINUE SALMON HABITAT ASSESSMENT FOR THE UPPER EKLUTNA RIVER ABOVE EKLUTNA LAKE IN THE UPPER EAST FORK. IN 2007 AND 2019, NVE PERFORMED HABITAT ASSESSMENT OF THE EKLUTNA RIVER BELOW THE LAKE TO THE INLET, AND THE UPPER EKLUTNA RIVER ABOVE THE LAKE WAS SURVEYED IN 2021 22, EXCEPT FOR THE UPPER PORTIONS OF THE EAST FORK.  ALL FIVE SPECIES ARE FOUND IN THE LOWER PORTIONS OF THE RIVER BELOW THE CONFLUENCE OF THUNDERBIRD CREEK. THE 2019 STUDY SHOWED THE HABITAT FOR SALMON EXISTS STILL, PENDING MORE WATERFLOW, UP TO THE EKLUTNA LAKE DAM. PRELIMINARY DATA AND TRADITIONAL ECOLOGICAL KNOWLEDGE (TEK) INDICATE ALL FIVE SPECIES OF SALMON USED THE ENTIRE EKLUTNA RIVER FOR THEIR LIFECYCLE. TEK ALSO INDICATES SALMON BEING FISHED OUT OF THE UPPER RIVER ABOVE THE LAKE, THOUGH NO SPECIFICS ABOUT WHICH SPECIES WERE CAUGHT.  NVE PROPOSES TO FINISH THE RIVER ASSESSMENT WORK TO THE UPPER SECTIONS OF THE RIVER FOR SALMON SPAWNING HABITAT. THE WORK WILL EXPAND UPON PREVIOUS WORK ON THE LOWER RIVER, BUT USE DIFFERENT METHODS TO DEFINE AND EVALUATE SPAWNING BED POTENTIAL IN THE UPPER RIVER. NVE ALSO PROPOSES TO CONTINUE SPAWNING SURVEYS, REDD COUNTS, AND MINNOW TRAPPING, BEGIN COLLECTING BASELINE GENETIC INFORMATION ON EKLUTNA RIVER SALMON, AND TO GATHER MORE DATA ON WATER INPUTS INTO THE LAKE BY MEASURING THE DISCHARGE FROM THE UPPER EAST AND WEST FORKS.  INTERAGENCY WORKING GROUP MEETINGS WILL CONTINUE TO CONSIDER THE RESULTS AND RECOMMEND TYPES OF FISH PASSAGES THAT WILL CORRESPOND TO THE FLOW RECOMMENDATION FROM PREVIOUS PROJECTS. THE DATA GATHERED IN THIS 2 YEAR STUDY WILL BE USED TO SUPPORT ONGOING ADVOCACY EFFORTS FOR THE IMPLEMENTATION OF A FISH PASSAGE AT THE EXISTING LAKE DAM AND TO FURTHER ADVOCATE FOR RESTORATION OF WATER TO THE LOWER EKLUTNA RIVER.

CHICKALOON NATIVE VILLAGE IS PROPOSING A MATANUSKA WATERSHED ADULT SALMON RESEARCH PROJECT. THIS PROJECT PROPOSES TO DESCRIBETHE RUN TIMING, ENUMERATION, AND SPECIES COMPOSITION OF ADULT ALASKA SALMON IN MOOSE CREEK, A MAIN TRIBUTARY OF THE MATANUSKAWATERSHED, USING VIDEO MONITORING EQUIPMENT AND A FISH WEIR, COLLECT BASELINE WATER QUALITY DATA ON MOOSE CREEK AND OTHERTRIBUTARIES OF THE MATANUSKA RIVER, AND BUILD PROGRAM CAPACITY FOR ADDITIONAL FISHERIES PROJECTS IN THE FUTURE. THIS PROJECT IS PROPOSEDTO LAST 12 MONTHS, FROM JANUARY 2023 THROUGH DECEMBER 2023. THIS PROJECT WILL BENEFIT SEVERAL ANADROMOUS SPECIES, INCLUDINGCULTURALLY SIGNIFICANT ALASKAN CHINOOK, COHO, CHUM, AND SOCKEYE SALMON. UNDERSTANDING WHEN MIGRATIONS OCCUR, NUMBERS OFRETURNING SPAWNING SALMON, AND SPECIES COMPOSITION FOR THIS TRIBUTARY ARE BENEFICIAL FOR RESOURCE MANAGEMENT DECISION MAKERS,INCLUDING FOR THE ESTABLISHMENT OF TRIBAL ORDINANCES ON LAND USE PRACTICES OR LAND USE GUIDELINES.

THE CHOCTAW NATION OF OKLAHOMA IS SEEKING FUNDING FROM THE US FISH AND WILDLIFE TRIBAL WILDLIFE GRANT  TWG  FOR  200,000 FOR THE PROPOSED PERIOD OF ONE YEAR STARTING DECEMBER 2, 2022 AND CONCLUDING DECEMBER 1, 2024.  THE ANTICIPATED FUNDING WILL BE UTILIZED TO DEVELOP A  1  TRIBAL FISH AND WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT PROGRAM COMPRISED OF DEVELOPMENT OF A WILDLIFE CONSERVATION MANAGEMENT PLAN  WMP  FOR WHITE-TAILED DEER IN ORDER TO EFFECTIVELY MANAGE THE SPECIES  2  IMPLEMENTATION OF WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT SOFTWARE TO MONITOR THE HARVESTING DATA FOR WHITE-TAILED DEER, AND  3  CONSULTATION WITH FEDERAL, STATE, LOCAL AND TRIBAL COMMUNITIES.

THE QUINAULT INDIAN NATION (QIN) NEEDS A SAFE AND EFFECTIVE METHOD FOR ESTIMATING ROOSEVELT ELK (CERVUS CANADENSIS ROOSEVELTI) POPULATIONS TO MAKE SCIENCE BASED MANAGEMENT DECISIONS. ROOSEVELT ELK ARE A CRUCIAL COMPONENT OF THE CULTURAL, SPIRITUAL, AND PHYSICAL HEALTH OF THE QUINAULT COMMUNITY. TRADITIONALLY, ELK POPULATIONS IN DENSE COASTAL TEMPERATE RAINFOREST ARE MONITORED USING DIRECT CAPTURE AND HELICOPTER SURVEYS. NEWER, SAFER METHODS FOR ESTIMATING LARGE MAMMAL ABUNDANCE VIA CAMERA TRAPPING HAVE BEEN DEVELOPED BUT ARE UNTESTED FOR ACCURACY AT ESTIMATING ELK ABUNDANCE IN THIS ENVIRONMENT. THE QIN WILDLIFE SECTION PROPOSES ESTIMATING ELK ABUNDANCE ON THE QUINAULT INDIAN RESERVATION (QIR) USING BOTH AN ESTABLISHED, WELL USED AERIAL MARK RESIGHT SURVEY APPROACH AND A NOVEL, NON INVASIVE CAMERA TRAPPING APPROACH, THEN COMPARING THE RESULTS FOR ACCURACY. THE PROPOSED PROJECT WILL DEPLOY 40 ELK COLLARS ON THE QIR AND CONDUCT TWO REPLICATED AERIAL MARK RESIGHT SURVEYS TO ESTIMATE ELK ABUNDANCE IN SPRING OF 2023. THE PROJECT WILL ALSO DEPLOY A 95 CAMERA GRID ACROSS THE QIR FOR SIX MONTHS IN 2022 AND 2023, CLASSIFYING RESULTANT IMAGES FOR SPECIES DETECTIONS AND INPUT INTO NEWER MODELS FOR ESTIMATING ABUNDANCE IN UNMARKED POPULATIONS. POPULATION ESTIMATES GENERATED FROM THE DIFFERENT METHODS WILL BE COMPARED AND MODEL PERFORMANCE EVALUATED BY EXAMINING STANDARD ERRORS AND CONFIDENCE INTERVALS. A DETERMINATION OF THE APPROPRIATENESS OF THE CAMERA TRAPPING METHODS FOR ESTIMATING ELK ABUNDANCE IN COASTAL TEMPERATE RAINFORESTS WILL BE MADE AND A LONG TERM MONITORING PROTOCOL FOR QIR ELK WILL BE RECOMMENDED.

THE PRIMARY GOAL OF THIS GRANT IS TO ACQUIRE FUNDING TO SUPPORT THE CONTINUED IMPLEMENTATION OF THE CANADA LYNX AUGMENTATION PROJECT. THIS PROJECT IS AN INTERNATIONAL EFFORT TO LIVE TRAP POPULATIONS OF LYNX FROM BRITISH COLUMBIA TO RELEASE ON THE COLVILLE INDIAN RESERVATION.  AN EXTENSIVE MONITORING PLAN IS IN PLACE TO TRACK AND ASSESS THE SUCCESS OF EACH LYNX THAT IS RELEASED AS PART OF THESE EFFORTS.  DURING THE 2021 2022 TRAPPING SEASON THE TRIBE, ALONG WITH PROJECT COLLABORATORS, WORKED WITH LOCAL TRAPPERS NEAR KELOWNA, BC AND TRAPPED AND PROCESSED 9 CANADA LYNX.  EACH LYNX WAS SEXED, AGED, ASSESSED FOR HEALTH AND FIT WITH A GPS RADIO COLLAR.  AFTER BEING TRANSPORTED ACROSS THE CANADIAN BORDER THE LYNX WERE TRANSPORTED TO THE COLVILLE INDIAN RESERVATION WHERE THEY WERE RELEASED IN ONE OF TWO AREAS THAT HAD BEEN CONSIDERED SUITABLE HABITAT. PROJECT BIOLOGISTS, TRAPPERS AND VETERINARIANS WORKED TOGETHER TO ENSURE THAT THE BEST AVAILABLE SCIENCE AND TECHNIQUES WERE USED DURING PROCESSING, TRANSPORT AND RELEASE TO ENSURE THE SAFETY AND WELLBEING OF EACH INDIVIDUAL LYNX. AN EXTENSIVE MONITORING EFFORT BEGAN AS SOON AS LYNX WERE RELEASED TO RECORD HABITAT USE, DAILY AND SEASONAL MOVEMENT, TERRITORY ESTABLISHMENT, BREEDING SUCCESS AND MORTALITY.  WE ANTICIPATE INCREASES IN BOTH DISTRIBUTION AND OCCURRENCE OF LYNX THROUGHOUT THE KETTLE RANGE AS WELL AS IN BRITISH COLUMBIA AND THE CASCADES.  THE TRUE REALIZATION OF THIS PROJECT LIES IN THE EVIDENCE OF LYNX REPRODUCTION IN THE AREA.  THIS SUCCESS MAY BE HARD TO DOCUMENT IN THE FIRST YEARS OF AUGMENTATION BUT THE TRIBE AND ITS PARTNERS ARE DEDICATED TO MONITORING AND PROTECTING THIS CULTURALLY IMPORTANT SPECIES AND WE WILL CONTINUE TO WORK TO RECOVER THIS SIGNIFICANT SPECIES.  IMPLEMENTING A PROJECT OF THIS SCOPE AND CAPACITY REQUIRES FUNDING FOR MULTIPLE YEARS. THE CONTINUED FUNDING OF THIS PROJECT WILL ALLOW TRIBAL BIOLOGISTS, ALONG WITH PARTNERS, TO CONTINUE THIS SIGNIFICANT WORK TO RETURN THE ENDANGERED CANADA LYNX TO THE KETTLE RANGE IN NORTHCENTRAL WASHINGTON.  CARRYING OUT THIS PROJECT ALLOWS THE TRIBE TO MANAGE A CULTURALLY SIGNIFICANT SPECIES ACROSS STATE, FEDERAL AND INTERNATIONAL BOUNDARIES, STRENGTHENING OUR TRIBAL SOVEREIGNTY.

THE COQUILLE INDIAN TRIBE IS PROPOSING TO USE TRIBAL WILDLIFE GRANT FUNDS TO COORDINATE AND CONDUCT A COMPREHENSIVE REVIEW AND UPDATE TO THE COQUILLE RIVER SUBBASIN PLAN (SUBBASIN PLAN) PREPARED FOR NOAA FISHERIES SERVICE IN 2007 IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT FRAMEWORK AND TIMELINES ESTABLISHED IN THE ORIGINAL DOCUMENT. THE SUBBASIN PLAN WAS ORIGINALLY PREPARED BY THE TRIBE OVER 15 YEARS AGO AND SINCE THEN HAS EFFECTIVELY SERVED TO GUIDE PRIORITIZATION OF PROJECT SCALE RESTORATION ACTIVITIES FOR THE BENEFIT OF NATIVE FISHES IN SOUTHWESTERN OREGONS COQUILLE RIVER WATERSHED. AS A WORKING DOCUMENT, IT WAS WRITTEN TO INCLUDE REGULAR UPDATES AND REVISIONS TO ENSURE THE BEST AVAILABLE SCIENCE IS UTILIZED. THE GOAL OF THIS PROPOSED PROJECT IS TO PRESERVE AND ENHANCE THE ORIGINAL INTENT OF THE SUBBASIN PLAN THROUGH  1) ENSURING THE BEST AVAILABLE SCIENTIFIC INFORMATION IS INCORPORATED  2) COORDINATING WITH STATE, FEDERAL, AND PRIVATE PARTNERS (STAKEHOLDERS)  3) EVALUATING THE RELEVANCE AND PRIORITY OF STRATEGIES ESTABLISHED IN 2007, INCLUDING THE PACE AND SCALE OF THEIR IMPLEMENTATION  AND 4) CONSIDERATION OF SPECIFICALLY EXPANDING THE SUITE OF FOCAL SPECIES ADDRESSED BEYOND OREGON COAST COHO SALMON TO ALSO INCLUDE FALL CHINOOK SALMON AND PACIFIC LAMPREY. GRANT FUNDS WILL ENABLE THE TRIBE TO ACCOMPLISH THIS GOAL BY SECURING THE SERVICES OF CONTRACTED EXPERTS, FUNDING STAFF TIME, AND FUNDING COORDINATION ACTIONS AND MEETINGS WITH STATE, FEDERAL, PRIVATE, AND OTHER PARTNERS. SUCCESSFUL COMPLETION OF THIS PROJECT WILL RESULT IN AN UP TO DATE PLANNING TOOL FOR THE BENEFIT OF RESTORATION PRACTITIONERS AND FISHERIES MANAGERS IN THE COQUILLE RIVER WATERSHED AND ULTIMATELY FOR BENEFIT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE RESOURCES OF THE WATERSHED AND THEIR USERS.

THE LUMMI NATION WILL RESTORE INSTREAM AND SIDE CHANNEL HABITAT IN THE SOUTH FORK (SF) NOOKSACK RIVER, WEST OF HWY 9, IN SKAGIT COUNTY (RM 17 16.5). THE GOAL IS TO RESTORE SF NOOKSACK EARLY CHINOOK SPAWNING, REARING AND HOLDING HABITAT TO RECOVER SELF SUSTAINING RUNS TO HARVESTABLE LEVELS BY ADDRESSING LIMITING FACTORS OF TEMPERATURE, HABITAT DIVERSITY, AND LACK OF KEY HABITAT. THE PROJECT WILL USE ENGINEERED LOG JAMS (ELJS) MODELED AFTER HISTORICAL SF LOG JAMS TO RESTORE GEOMORPHIC AND HABITAT FORMING PROCESSES. RESTORATION ELEMENTS INCLUDE THE CONSTRUCTION OF 13 ELJS, 1 CHANNEL SPANNING ELJ, 4 HABITAT STRUCTURES, AND THE PLANTING OF 7.3 RIPARIAN ACRES. SIMILAR TO OTHER SUCCESSFUL UPPER SF PROJECTS COMPLETED BY LUMMI NATION, THE PROJECT WILL COMBAT INCISION, AGGRADE THE CHANNEL, ENCOURAGE SPLIT FLOWS AND ANABRANCHING CHANNEL FORM, INCREASE SIDE CHANNEL HABITAT AND FLOODPLAIN CONNECTIVITY, ENHANCE A COOL WATER TRIBUTARY CHANNEL, CREATE THERMAL REFUGIA AND LOW FLOW POOL HABITAT, AND PROVIDE SHADE AND WOOD RECRUITMENT. THE WRIA 1 SALMONID RECOVERY PLAN IDENTIFIED SF EARLY CHINOOK AS ONE OF THE HIGHEST PRIORITY POPULATIONS  IT IS ESSENTIAL FOR RECOVERY OF THE THREATENED PUGET SOUND ESU. THE PROJECT ENHANCES BENEFITS OF THE SF CHINOOK RESCUE PROGRAM, A NATIVE BROODSTOCK HATCHERY PROGRAM SUPPORTING RECOVERY, AND ADDRESSES A TEMPERATURE TMDL ON A RIVER THREATENED BY CLIMATE CHANGE. THE PROJECT WILL ALSO BENEFIT ESA LISTED STEELHEAD AND BULL TROUT  COHO, SOCKEYE, AND PINK SALMON  AND THE SOUTHERN RESIDENT KILLER WHALE.

THE TULALIP TRIBES IS UTILIZING A UNIQUE, NATURE BASED APPROACH TO RESTORE SALMON POPULATIONS AND THEIR HABITAT WITHIN THEIR USUAL AND ACCUSTOMED HUNTING AND FISHING AREA. THROUGH THE TULALIP BEAVER PROJECT,  NUISANCE  BEAVERS ARE LIVE TRAPPED FROM URBAN AREAS AROUND PUGET SOUND WHERE COEXISTENCE IS NOT POSSIBLE. THESE BEAVERS ARE THEN RELOCATED TO REMOTE STREAMS IN THE SNOHOMISH AND STILLAGUAMISH WATERSHEDS ON UNITED STATES FOREST SERVICE LAND WHERE THEIR DAM BUILDING ACTIVITIES WILL COMPLETELY TRANSFORM THE LANDSCAPE. BY BUILDING DAMS AT RELOCATION SITES, BEAVERS WILL PROTECT, CREATE, AND RESTORE VITAL AQUATIC, RIPARIAN, AND WETLAND HABITAT FOR SALMON AND OTHER NATIVE WILDLIFE. TULALIP BEAVER PROJECT STAFF MONITOR THEIR BEAVER RELOCATION SITES FOR BEAVER ACTIVITY, CHANGES IN HABITAT, WILDLIFE PRESENCE, AND SALMON SPAWNING AND REARING. AS BEAVERS CREATE A VAST NETWORK OF DAMS THERE WILL BE AN INCREASE IN SALMON HABITAT AND SALMON POPULATIONS ALL WHILE MAKING THESE WATERSHEDS MORE RESILIENT TO THE EFFECTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE.

THE TRIBE WILL WORK IN PARTNERSHIP WITH CONSULTANTS, LOCAL PARTNERS, OTHER TRIBES, USFWS, AND NMFS TO DEVELOP ATRIBAL CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT PLAN THAT WILL TIER TO THE TRIBES  FMP AND PROVIDE A FRAMEWORK FOR MANAGINGTRIBAL FOREST LANDS WHILE PROMOTING SCIENCE DRIVEN MANAGEMENT PRINCIPLES FOR SENSITIVE FISH AND WILDLIFE SPECIES.THE PLAN WILL BE DEVELOPED USING THE BEST AVAILABLE SCIENTIFIC AND COMMERCIAL DATA IN ADDITION TO TEK.

TO THE PEOPLE OF THE YAVAPAI-APACHE NATION THE VERDE RIVER (TU CHO N'LII) AND ITS ASSOCIATED WETLAND/RIPARIAN ZONE IS AN IMPORTANT PHYSICAL AND SPIRITUAL ANCHOR TO THEIR PLACE IN THIS WORLD. THE VERDE RIVER AND ITS RIPARIAN HABITAT HAVE ALWAYS BEEN AND REMAINS TODAY THE FOCAL POINT OF THE YAVAPAI AND APACHE PEOPLES' EXISTENCE.THE AQUATIC, WETLAND, AND RIPARIAN ECOSYSTEMS OF THE VERDE RIVER HAVE BEEN GREATLY ALTERED AND REDUCED BY OVER A CENTURY OF WATER DEVELOPMENT PROJECTS, DEFORESTATION, AGRICULTURE AND DEVELOPMENT, AND NON-NATIVE SPECIES INVASION. THESE ACTIVITIES HAVE IMPACTED NATIVE STANDS OF COTTONWOOD, WILLOW, MESQUITE, AND A VARIETY OF NATIVE GRASS, FORB, AND SHRUB COMMUNITIES FURTHER PROMOTING THE ESTABLISHMENT AND PROLIFERATION OF NON-NATIVE, INVASIVE SPECIES SUCH AS SALT CEDAR AND COMMON REED. SEASONAL FLOODING THAT PROVIDED ALLUVIAL SEED BEDS OF NATIVE COTTONWOOD AND WILLOW HAVE CEASED TO OCCUR CAUSING THE DEMISE OF NATURAL RECRUITMENT OF THESE SPECIES AS WELL AS ENDING THE NATURAL PROCESS OF SOIL DESALINIZATION. THE ECOLOGICAL INTEGRITY OF THIS SYSTEM HAS BEEN COMPROMISED, WHICH HAS FOSTERED THE GROWTH OF LOW QUALITY HABITAT DOMINATED BY SALT CEDAR AND COMMON REEDS. WILDLIFE SPECIES, PARTICULARLY RESIDENT AND MIGRATORY BIRD POPULATIONS, HAVE DECLINED WITH THE LOSS OF SUITABLE COTTONWOOD/WILLOW AND BULRUSH/CATTAIL HABITAT. IN THE ARID SOUTHWEST, NATIVE WETLAND AND RIPARIAN HABITATS HAVE HIGHER SPECIES DIVERSITY AND DENSITY THAN ANY OTHER .HABITAT TYPE IN THE OVERALL LANDSCAPE. THEREFORE, IMPACTS TO THESE HABITATS CAUSE A DISPROPORTIONATE THREAT TO REGIONAL SPECIES DIVERSITY.OBJECTIVES: (FROM: TRACS STRATEGY FACT SHEET - DIRECT HABITAT AND SPECIES MANAGEMENT)DIRECTLY RESTORE AND/OR ENHANCE APPROXIMATELY 207 ACRES OF VERDE RIVER RIPARIAN CORRIDOR WITHIN THE YAVAPAI-APACHE NATION RESERVATION BY 6-30-2022.- INVASIVE SPECIES CONTROL (PLANTS) - REMOVE APPROXIMATELY 90% OF INVASIVE PLANT SPECIES IN THE IDENTIFIED PROJECT SITES (207 ACRES)- PLANTING/SEEDING - ESTABLISH/ENHANCE 80 ACRES OF SELF-SUSTAINING NATIVE RIPARIAN HABITAT, INCLUDING COTTONWOOD, WILLOW, MESQUITE AND OTHER NATIVE SPECIES. THIS WILL ALLOW FOR PROTECTION OF THE CRITICAL HABITAT THAT IS ASSOCIATED WITH THE VERDE RIVER RIPARIAN ZONE.DIRECTLY RESTORE AND/OR ENHANCE 0.75 MILES OF VERDE RIVER STREAM BANKS BY 6-30 -2022.- RIVER/STREAM MANAGEMENT - ESTABLISH/ENHANCE 0.75 MILES OF SELF-SUSTAINING NATIVE RIPARIAN HABITAT, INCLUDING COTTONWOOD, WILLOW, MESQUITE AND OTHER NATIVE SPECIES ALONG THE RIVER BANKS OF THE VERDE RIVER WITHIN THE PROJECT SITES.

THE OVERALL GOAL FOR THE KAIBAB BAND OF PAIUTE INDIANS WILDLIFE, FISHERIES AND PARKS DEPARTMENT IS TO CONTINUE TODEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT BENEFICIAL PROGRAMS FOR THE WILDLIFE AND THEIR HABITAT WITHIN THE RESERVATION, ESPECIALLYCULTURAL AND TRADITIONAL SPECIES. THE MAIN OBJECTIVE FOR THIS GRANT PROJECT IS TO PROACTIVELY MANAGE DESERTBIGHORN SHEEP POPULATIONS TO INCREASE THEIR HERD NUMBERS. THE DEPARTMENT UNDERSTANDS THAT ACHIEVING ITS GOALSAND OBJECTIVES WILL REQUIRE RESEARCH, EDUCATION, WILDLIFE MONITORING, MAPPING AND LONG-TERM PLANNING MADEPOSSIBLE WITH INCREASED DEPARTMENT STAFF. FUNDING FROM THIS GRANT WILL BUILD TRIBAL CAPACITY WITHIN THEDEPARTMENT BY RETAINING OUR WILDLIFE TECHNICIAN, AND ALLOW THE WILDLIFE, FISHERIES AND PARKS DEPARTMENT TO GPSCOLLAR TWO ADDITIONAL DESERT BIGHORN SHEEP FOR COMPLETION OF A MIGRATION STUDY TO BETTER MANAGE RESERVATIONWILDLIFE RESOURCES.THE PROJECT WILL CONTRIBUTE TO TRIBAL SELF-SUFFICIENCY IN WILDLIFE RESOURCE MANAGEMENT BY INCREASING STAFF,TRAINING LEVELS, AND BY PROVIDING A HUNTING CAPACITY GUIDELINE TO IMPROVE HUNT REVENUE STREAMS. THE RESEARCHRESULTING FROM THIS PROJECT IS THE FIRST STEP TOWARDS PROPER CONSERVATION PRACTICES. BASELINE WILDLIFE DATA WILLBE VITAL FOR FUTURE WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT DECISIONS. THE ULTIMATE OUTCOME FOR THE TRIBE WILL BE DOCUMENTED HERDPOPULATIONS WHICH CAN BE EVALUATED FOR ANNUAL BIGHORN SHEEP HUNTS, THEREBY SUSTAINABLY MANAGING HEALTHY SPECIESAND MAXIMIZING REVENUE TO PERPETUATE THE PROGRAM. THE PROPOSED PROJECT WILL BE AN 18- MONTH DURATION.

THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS STUDY IS TO CREATE SUITABLE HABITAT FOR WILD TURKEY THAT ARE CURRENTLY DECLINING. WE ARE SEEKING TO BETTER UNDERSTAND THE SPECIES USE OF OUR LAND AND TO OPTIMIZE THE HABITAT FOR THEIR BENEFIT. WE WILL BE CAPTURING WILD SPECIMENS AND PLACING GPS TRACKERS ON THE SPECIMENS TO DETERMINE THEIR TIME SPENT IN EACH HABITAT TYPE. WE WILL BE MODIFYING HABITAT TO PROPERLY SUIT THE DECLINING SPECIES AND ARE USING THESE FUNDS TO HAVE THE EQUIPMENT NECESSARY TO DO SO.WE WILL BE MEASURING OUR POPULATIONS AND ACTIVITIES BY DOING GOBBLING SURVEYS, "BY CHANCE" OBSERVATIONS, AND POULT COUNTS. WE WILL BE ABLE TO USE THE TELEMETRY TOOLS, WILDLIFE CAPTURE AND PRESCRIBED FIRE EQUIPMENT FOR NOT ONLY THIS STUDY, BUT FOR FUTURE ENDEAVORS AS WELL. WE WILL BE WORKING SPECIFICALLY ON 910 ACRES AND CAN SCALE IT UP TO OVER 4,000 ACRES IN THE FUTURE.WE WILL BE WORKING ON EDUCATIONAL VIDEOS AND EVENTS TO TEACH OTHER LANDOWNERS AND USERS OF OUR LAND TO PROPERLY MANAGE OUR WILDLIFE POPULATIONS FOR FUTURE GENERATIONS.

THE PROPOSED PROJECT WILL PROVIDE SUPPORT FOR SHINNECOCK INDIAN NATION TO ENGAGE IN FISH AND WILDLIFE CONSERVATION EFFORTS ON THEIR HISTORIC LANDS. THE SHINNECOCK SUSTAINABLE SHELLFISH PROJECT IS A PLAN TO RESTORE AND ESTABLISH A SUSTAINABLE SHELLFISH STOCK IN WATERS ADJACENT TO THE SHINNECOCK INDIAN RESERVATION. THIS PROJECT HAS THE FOLLOWING OBJECTIVES: EXPANSION OF AN EXISTING OYSTER REEF ON THE SHINNECOCK RESERVATIONS SOUTHWESTERN SHORELINE BY 150 LINEAR FEET, RETROFITTING THE SHINNECOCK SHELLFISH HATCHERY TO INCREASE OUTPUT CAPACITY AND FREE PLANTING OF QUAHOG CLAMS AND INDIVIDUAL OYSTERS WITHIN SHINNECOCK BAY ADJACENT TO THE TRIBAL LANDS. THIS PROJECT WILL ENHANCE THE CAPACITY FOR SHINNECOCK NATION TO PRODUCE AND GROW OUT THEIR OWN SHELLFISH. THE PROJECT ALSO SEEKS TO ENGAGE COMMUNITY SHELLFISH HARVESTERS IN THE PROCESS, WITH THE HOPE OF FOSTERING INCREASED STEWARDSHIP VALUES AND A GENERAL INTEREST IN SHELLFISH MANAGEMENT. THE SHINNECOCK NATION WILL BE PARTNERING WITH CORNELL COOPERATIVE EXTENSION OF SUFFOLK COUNTY ON THIS PROJECT. THE CURRENT PROJECT WILL TAKE PLACE OVER THE COURSE OF 12 MONTHS, AND WILL CREATE LASTING LONG-TERM BENEFITS FOR TRIBAL MEMBERS AND THE SURROUNDING ENVIRONMENT.

THE PEOPLE OF THE PUEBLO OF SANTA ANA (THE "PUEBLO") HAVE LIVED ALONG THE BANKS OF THE RIO GRANDE AND RIO JEMEZ FOR OVER 400 YEARS. THEY HAVE ENDURED THROUGH THE CENTURIES BY MAINTAINING THEIR TRADITIONAL, CULTURAL, AND SPIRITUAL WAYS THAT ARE STRONGLY INFLUENCED BY THEIR CONNECTION TO THE NATURAL WORLD. LIKE MANY OTHER TRIBES, THIS CONNECTION INVOLVES THE USE OF TRADITIONALLY IMPORTANT WILDLIFE SUCH AS MULE DEER (ODOCOILEUS HEMIONUS), ROCKY MOUNTAIN ELK (CERVUS ELAPHUS), PRONGHORN (ANTILOCAPRA AMERICANA), BLACK BEAR (URSUS AMERICANUS), AND MOUNTAIN LION (PUMA CONCOLOR).BECAUSE THESE SPECIES HAVE SIGNIFICANT CULTURAL AND SPIRITUAL RELEVANCE, IT IS IMPORTANT TO THE PUEBLO TO ENSURE SUSTAINABLE POPULATIONS ON THEIR LANDS FOR CURRENT AND FUTURE GENERATIONS. A CHALLENGE TO THIS IS THAT WILDLIFE MOVEMENT AND WILDLIFE-VEHICLE COLLISION DATA SHOWED THAT MOVEMENT CORRIDORS FOR THESE SPECIES ARE AFFECTED BY TWO MAJOR ROADWAYS THAT BISECT THE PUEBLO.THIS WAS RECENTLY CONFIRMED BY STATE OF NEW MEXICO WHEN THEY CLASSIFIED THE SANDIA-JEMEZ MOUNTAIN CORRIDOR AS ONE OF THE TOP 10 HABITAT LINKAGES IN THE STATE THAT ARE THREATENED BY ROADS- AND THIS LINKAGE RUNS STRAIGHT THROUGH THE PUEBLO. THIS CLASSIFICATION PROVIDES AN OPPORTUNITY FOR THE PUEBLO TO WORK WITH STATE AND FEDERAL PARTNERS TO DESIGN AND CONSTRUCT WILDLIFE-VEHICLE COLLISION MITIGATION PROJECTS (WVCMP) THAT PROTECT MOTORISTS AND PROMOTE WILDLIFE CONNECTIVITY. HOWEVER, BEFORE THIS CAN HAPPEN, DATA WILL NEED TO BE COLLECTED TO IDENTIFY AND QUANTIFY WILDLIFE USE OF EXISTING BRIDGES AND CULVERTS TO CROSS ROADWAYS.THEREFORE, THE PUEBLO IS PROPOSING TO 1) DEVELOP A WILDLIFE CROSSING BASELINE DATASET THAT CAN BE USED TO HELP IN THE DESIGN OF FUTURE WVCMPS, 2) IMPROVE MOTORIST'S ABILITY TO DETECT AND AVOID COLLIDING WITH WILDLIFE IN KNOWN WILDLIFE-VEHICLE COLLISION HOTSPOTS, AND 3) GARNER SUPPORT FROM COMMUNITY MEMBERS FOR FUTURE CONSTRUCTION OF WVCMPS ON THEIR LAND. THE PROPOSED PROJECT IS IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE NEW MEXICO DEPARTMENT OF GAME AND FISH, NEW MEXICO DEPARTMENT OF TRANSPORTATION, NATIONAL WILDLIFE FEDERATION, AND THE NEW MEXICO WILDLIFE CORRIDORS ACTION PLAN TEAM. FURTHERMORE, THE PROPOSED PROJECT INVOLVES BUILDING THE PUEBLO'S CAPACITY TO 1) PROVIDE FOR THE BENEFIT AND PROTECTION OF WILDLIFE AND 2) EDUCATE THE COMMUNITY ABOUT WILDLIFE CONNECTIVITY. LASTLY, THE PROPOSED PROJECT WILL CONTRIBUTE TO IMPROVING LOCAL AND REGIONAL WILDLIFE CONNECTIVITY BY ADDING A TRIBAL LINK INTO THE WILDLIFE CONNECTIVITY CHAIN THAT STRETCHES ACROSS THE WESTERN UNITED STATES.

THE HOOPA PACIFIC LAMPREY PASSAGE PROJECT WILL SPECIFICALLY ADDRESS PASSAGE ISSUES IN THE TRINITY RIVER BASIN AND PROVIDE VALUABLE INFORMATION APPLICABLE TO REGIONAL LAMPREY CONSERVATION EFFORTS BY LOCAL TRIBES AND OTHER STAKEHOLDERS. THE PROJECT INCLUDES A) FIELD TESTS USING LOCALLY CAUGHT ADULT LAMPREYS AT ACTUAL PASSAGE IMPEDIMENTS IN THE TRINITY DRAINAGE, B) CONSTRUCTION OF A SMALL REGIONAL TESTING FACILITY, C) CRITICAL ASSESSMENT OF LAMPREY PASSAGE POTENTIAL AT PRINCIPAL CULVERTS AND OTHER IMPEDIMENTS IN THE TRINITY BASIN, D) FIELD AND LAB TESTING OF POTENTIAL RETROFITS TO EXISTING IMPEDIMENTS, AND E) EDUCATIONAL OUTREACH TO TRIBAL MEMBERSHIP, LOCAL STAKEHOLDERS AND MANAGERS (CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF TRANSPORTATION, COUNTY PUBLIC WORKS DEPARTMENTS, USFS, USFWS, NOAA, CDFG, ETC.). THE HOOPA VALLEY FISHERIES DEPARTMENT HAS PREVIOUSLY APPLIED AND RECEIVED FUNDING THROUGH THIS PROGRAM AND A REPORT ON LAMPREY PASSAGE IN THE TRINITY RIVER BASIN WAS PREPARED BY DR. STEWART REID OF WESTERN FISHES (2016). ADDITIONALLY, THE COLLABORATION BETWEEN THE HOOPA FISHERIES PROGRAM AND DR. REID IN 2016 LED TO A LAMPREY TEST FACILITY ON THE VAN ARSDALE DAM AND MULTIPLE PAPERS.

THE SUN AQ TRIBE OF KODIAK (SUN AQ) REMAINS GRAVELY CONCERNED ABOUT THE PRESENCE OF INVASIVE SIGNAL CRAYFISH (PACIFASTACUS LENIUSCULUS) IN THE BUSKIN RIVER WATERSHED AND THEIR POTENTIAL IMPACT ON WILD SALMON STOCKS VITAL TO THE SUBSISTENCE CULTURE AND LIFESTYLE OF SUN AQ TRIBAL CITIZENS AS WELL AS NON-TRIBAL MEMBERS OF THE KODIAK COMMUNITY. THE EFFECTS WITHIN THE BUSKIN WATERSHED COULD IMPACT SALMON HABITAT AND SURVIVAL, THOUGH THE COMPLETE IMPLICATIONS OF SIGNAL CRAYFISH WITHIN THE WATERSHED AND THE METHOD OF INTRODUCTION ARE NOT YET FULLY KNOWN. SINCE THE INITIAL REPORTS TWO DECADES AGO, THESE CRAYFISH HAVE SUBSEQUENTLY INVADED BUSKIN LAKE AND AREAS OF THE BUSKIN RIVER. THIS TWO-YEAR PROJECT WILL ENABLE MONITORING, MANAGEMENT, AND COMMUNITY INVOLVEMENT WITH RESEARCH EFFORTS TO BETTER UNDERSTAND FUNDAMENTAL POPULATION DYNAMICS OF THE SIGNAL CRAYFISH IN THE BUSKIN WATERSHED THROUGH THREE PRIMARY ELEMENTS: 1) ENVIRONMENTAL DNA MONITORING THROUGHOUT THE WATERSHED TO DETERMINE THE EXTENT OF SIGNAL CRAYFISH PROPAGATION; 2) ACOUSTIC TAGGING TO DETERMINE MOVEMENT PATTERNS, SEASONALITY, DIURNAL/NOCTURNAL ACTIVITY PATTERNS, AND BEHAVIOR AROUND CRAYFISHING TRAPS TO BETTER INFORM OUR UNDERSTANDING OF CRAYFISH BEHAVIOR TO REFINE ERADICATION EFFORTS; AND 3) A MARK-RECAPTURE STUDY TO BE HELD IN CONJUNCTION WITH A SEASON-LONG "FISHING DERBY" TO CREATE A LARGE DATASET, REMOVE AS MANY CRAYFISH AS POSSIBLE, AND INCREASE OUR EDUCATION AND PUBLIC OUTREACH OF THE THREATS OF THIS INVASIVE SPECIES.

ALASKA'S ENDANGERED COOK INLET BELUGA WHALE (DELPHINAPTERUS LEUCAS) POPULATION IS AN IMPORTANT CULTURAL RESOURCE FOR ALASKA NATIVES, INCLUDING THE KNIK TRIBE, WHO HAVE TRADITIONALLY HUNTED, UTILIZED, AND TRADED THEM. THIS SUBSISTENCE TRADITION IS NO LONGER PERMITTED DUE TO THE DRASTIC DECLINE IN THIS ENDANGERED POPULATION. THE KNIK TRIBE IS ACTIVELY INVOLVED IN HELPING TO UNDERSTAND AND REVERSE THIS DECLINE AND SEEKS FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE TO CONTINUE TO DO SO. WE THEREFORE PROPOSE TO: 1) FILL DATA GAPS IN A LONG-TERM (2005-2021) COOK INLET BELUGA WHALE PHOTO-IDENTIFICATION CATALOG, 2) USE THESE DATA TO REFINE RECENTLY DEVELOPED POPULATION MODELS TO REDUCE BIAS AND INCREASE PRECISION IN ESTIMATES OF DEMOGRAPHIC RATES, POPULATION VIABILITY, AND EXTINCTION RISKS, 3) ANALYZE BELUGA SOCIAL STRUCTURE AND HOW IT MAY AFFECT RECOVERY, 4) INCREASE ENGAGEMENT OF KNIK TRIBE MEMBERS IN SHARING BELUGA SIGHTINGS AND INFORMATION, AND 5) INCREASE REPRESENTATION OF THE KNIK TRIBE AND OTHER COOK INLET TRIBES IN CONSERVATION EFFORTS FOR THE BELUGA. OUR PROPOSED DELIVERABLES ARE AS FOLLOWS: UPDATED AND REFINED ESTIMATES OF COOK INLET BELUGA WHALE REPRODUCTIVE AND SURVIVAL RATES THAT FOR THE FIRST TIME HIGHLIGHT INTERANNUAL VARIABILITY IN DEMOGRAPHY, POPULATION VIABILITY, AND EXTINCTION RISK THAT INCLUDE ROBUST ESTIMATES OF FECUNDITY AND IMPROVE CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT INSIGHTS COMPILED IN A MANUSCRIPT REPORTING THESE UPDATES; ANALYSIS OF BELUGA SOCIAL STRUCTURE AND A MANUSCRIPT REPORTING OUR FINDINGS; DEVELOPMENT OF A KNIK TRIBE-SPECIFIC WEBPAGE FOR REPORTING BELUGA SIGHTINGS IN ENGLISH AND DENA'INA; AND FOUR SEMI-ANNUAL MEETINGS AMONG THE KNIK TRIBE AND INVITED NATIVE ALASKAN GROUPS IN COOK INLET TO SHARE INFORMATION ABOUT BELUGA RESEARCH METHODS AND FINDINGS, AND STRATEGIZE ABOUT INCREASED TRIBAL INVOLVEMENT IN COOK INLET BELUGA WHALE CONSERVATION AND RESEARCH.

PROJECT OBJECTIVES ARE FOCUSED ON THE CONTINUATION OF AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES (AIS) PREVENTION,EARLY-DETECTION MONITORING, ERADICATION AND CONTROL, AND EDUCATION EFFORTS FOR THE PYRAMID LAKEPAIUTE TRIBE (PLPT). THE OBJECTIVES OF THIS PROPOSAL CONCENTRATE ON THE PRESERVATION OF THEFEDERALLY ENDANGERED CUI-UI AND THREATENED LAHONTAN CUTTHROAT TROUT AND THE NATURAL, CULTURAL,RECREATIONAL, AND ECONOMIC RESOURCES OF THE PYRAMID LAKE PAIUTE TRIBE THROUGH INCREASEDCAPACITY TO CONTINUE AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES PREVENTION AND MANAGEMENT ON THE PYRAMID LAKEPAIUTE RESERVATION (PLPR).THE PROPOSED PROJECT IS VITAL TO INCREASE PROGRAM CAPACITY OF TRIBAL WILDLIFE PROTECTION ANDCONSERVATION. THE PLPT IS REQUESTING $197,718 IN TRIBAL WILDLIFE PROGRAM FUNDING FOR A PROJECTPERIOD OF ONE YEAR FOR ACTIONS RELATED TO AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES PREVENTION, EARLY-DETECTIONMONITORING, CONTROL, ERADICATION, AND PUBLIC EDUCATION ON THE PYRAMID LAKE PAIUTE RESERVATION.THE PROPOSED PROJECT BUILDS OFF PROGRAMING DEVELOPED IN 2018 WITH THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THEPYRAMID LAKE PAIUTE TRIBE'S AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES PROGRAM THAT BEGAN EARLY-DETECTIONMONITORING, MANAGEMENT, AND EDUCATION TO COMPLEMENT EFFORTS ALREADY IN PLACE BY PYRAMID LAKEFISHERIES, NEVADA DEPARTMENT OF WILDLIFE, U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICES, AND BUREAU OFRECLAMATION TO AID IN THE RECOVERY OF THE THREATENED LAHONTAN CUTTHROAT TROUT AND ENDANGEREDCUI-UI. THE PROPOSED PROJECT IS VITAL TO INCREASE PROGRAM CAPACITY TO PREVENT THE SPREAD OF AQUATICINVASIVE SPECIES THROUGH WATERCRAFT INSPECTIONS AND DECONTAMINATIONS AND PROVIDING PUBLICEDUCATION AS WELL AS CONTINUE AIS MANAGEMENT WITHIN THE PLPR. DELIVERABLES INCLUDE, UPDATEAND MAINTAIN A COMPREHENSIVE PLPT AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES MANAGEMENT PLAN AND STANDARDOPERATING PROCEDURES, DEVELOP A RAPID RESPONSE PLAN; DEVELOP AN INSPECTION ANDDECONTAMINATION FEE FOR PROGRAM SUSTAINABILITY; DEVELOP A PROCESS FOR DATA SHARING ANDCOMMUNICATION WITH REGIONAL GROUPS ON AIS MANAGEMENT PROTOCOLS AND NEW AIS INFESTATIONS;CONDUCT EARLY-DETECTION MONITORING, CONTROL, AND ERADICATION OF AIS AND REPORT ON POST-PROJECTACCOMPLISHMENTS; COORDINATE WITH TRIBAL POLICE OFFICERS AND RANGERS TO ENFORCE TRIBALREGULATIONS REGARDING AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES; DEVELOP CONTENT AND PRESENT AT A TRIBAL YOUTHEDUCATION DAY; PLAN AND CONDUCT A VOLUNTEER DAY FOR TRIBAL MEMBERS AND REGIONAL GROUPS FOR AISEDUCATION, IDENTIFICATION, AND MANAGEMENT IN THE LOWER TRUCKEE RIVER; AND DEVELOP OUTREACHMATERIAL AND PROVIDE EDUCATION ON AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES.CAPACITY BUILDING TO INCREASE PUBLIC EDUCATION, PROVIDE INSPECTIONS AND DECONTAMINATIONS, ANDCONTINUE AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES MANAGEMENT EFFORTS WILL HELP ENSURE AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIESARE NOT SPREAD TO PYRAMID LAKE PAIUTE RESERVATION WATERS AND ADVERSELY IMPACT NATIVE FISHSPECIES. THIS PROGRAM WILL BUILD UPON THE PLPT'S ONGOING EFFORTS TO CONDUCT AQUATIC INVASIVESPECIES EARLY-DETECTION MONITORING, MANAGEMENT, CONTROL AND ERADICATION, AND PUBLIC OUTREACHAND CAN PROVIDE A FOUNDATION FOR OTHER ENTITIES TO ESTABLISH AIS MANAGEMENT PROGRAMS ANDPREVENT THE SPREAD OF AIS THROUGH DATA SHARING, REGIONAL COMMUNICATIONS, AND REPORTING OFRESULTS.

THIS PROJECT PROVIDES BENEFITS TO TRIBAL FISH AND FISH HABITAT AND INCREASES THE HOONAH INDIAN ASSOCIATION'S CAPACITY TO ASSIST WITH FISHERIES MANAGEMENT OF CULTURALLY IMPORTANT ANADROMOUS SPECIES. THE ANADROMOUS WATERS CATALOG FOR THE LOCAL HOONAH AREA CONTAINS DATA GAPS AND INCONSISTENCIES THAT COULD BE SIGNIFICANTLY IMPROVED THROUGH COLLABORATION WITH THE HOONAH NATIVE FOREST PARTNERSHIP. THE INCREASED CAPACITY RESULTING FROM THE PROJECT WILL ASSIST IN THE GROWTH OF A FISHERIES PROGRAM AND PURSUIT IN MANAGEMENT AND MONITORING OF LOCAL SALMON RESOURCES FOR SUBSISTENCE. THIS WILL ALLOW BETTER-INFORMED FISHERIES MODELS THAT AFFECT LAND MANAGEMENT DECISIONS THAT DIRECTLY AFFECT ANADROMOUS FISH PASSAGES, ENHANCEMENT, AND STREAM RESTORATION. DATA WILL BE GATHERED FROM AT LEAST 50 STREAMS AND WILL BE INTEGRATED INTO THE STATEWIDE ANADROMOUS WATERS CATALOG DATABASE FOR THE USE OF ANYONE IN THE STATE OF ALASKA AND BY LAND MANAGERS OF THE HOONAH NATIVE FOREST PARTNERSHIP. IN ADDITION, THE PROJECT WILL CREATE A BETTER-INFORMED MODEL FOR END OF FISH MODELING. THE HOONAH NATIVE FOREST PARTNERSHIP WILL WORK TO GATHER DATA THROUGH ELECTRO-SHOCKING PROTOCOLS DURING THE SUMMER OF 2022. SOCIAL MEDIA POSTS WILL BE PUBLISHED MONTHLY FROM FEBRUARY THROUGH SEPTEMBER 2022, AN END OF PROGRAM BLOG POST WILL BE SHARED, AND A VIDEO OF THE PROJECT WILL BE PREPARED WITH ACCREDITATION TO ALL PARTNERS AND THE TRIBAL WILDLIFE GRANT FUNDING SOURCE. LASTLY, THE FISHERIES REPORT WILL BE SUBMITTED TO THE STATE OF ALASKA WITH ANADROMOUS WATERS CATALOG NOMINATION IN OCTOBER 2022. AN INCREASE OF COMMUNITY AWARENESS WILL RESULT FROM THE PROJECT'S OUTREACH VIA COMMUNITY MEETINGS FOCUSED ON FISHERIES ISSUES AND DIGITAL OUTREACH THROUGH HOONAH INDIAN ASSOCIATION'S SOCIAL MEDIA AND WEBSITE PLATFORMS.
